revision.text:
{{main|ISO 3166-2}} '''ISO 3166-2:NR''' is the entry for [[Nauru]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]]. Currently for Nauru, ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[districts of Nauru|14 districts]]. Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|NR}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of Nauru. The second part is two digits (01–14). ==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA). ''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Subdivision name ([[English language|en]], [[Nauruan language|na]]) |- | {{mono|NR-01}} | [[Aiwo District|Aiwo]] |- | {{mono|NR-02}} | [[Anabar District|Anabar]] |- | {{mono|NR-03}} | [[Anetan District|Anetan]] |- | {{mono|NR-04}} | [[Anibare District|Anibare]] |- | {{mono|NR-05}} | [[Baiti District|Baitsi]] (local variant is Baiti) |- | {{mono|NR-06}} | [[Boe District|Boe]] |- | {{mono|NR-07}} | [[Buada District|Buada]] |- | {{mono|NR-08}} | [[Denigomodu District|Denigomodu]] |- | {{mono|NR-09}} | [[Ewa District, Nauru|Ewa]] |- | {{mono|NR-10}} | [[Ijuw District|Ijuw]] |- | {{mono|NR-11}} | [[Meneng District|Meneng]] |- | {{mono|NR-12}} | [[Nibok District|Nibok]] |- | {{mono|NR-13}} | [[Uaboe District|Uaboe]] |- | {{mono|NR-14}} | [[Yaren District|Yaren]] |} ==Changes== The following changes to the entry have been announced by the ISO 3166/MA since the first publication of ISO 3166-2 in 1998. ISO stopped issuing newsletters in 2013. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Newsletter ! Date issued ! Description of change in newsletter ! Code/Subdivision change |- | id="I-8" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_i-8_en.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter I-8}}] | {{nowrap|2007-04-17}} | Addition of the administrative subdivisions and of their code elements | style=white-space:nowrap | '''Subdivisions added:'''
14 districts |- | id="II-3" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_ii-3_2011-12-13.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter II-3}}] | {{nowrap|2011-12-13}}
''(corrected
{{nowrap|2011-12-15}})'' | Local generic administrative term addition. | |- | [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:NR Online Browsing
Platform (OBP)] | 2017-11-23 | Change of subdivision name of NR-05; addition of local variation of NR-05, update List Source | '''Name changed:'''
{{mono|NR-05}} Baiti → Baitsi |} ==See also== * [[Subdivisions of Nauru]] * [[List of FIPS region codes (M-O)#NR: Nauru|FIPS region codes of Nauru]] ==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:NR ISO Online Browsing Platform: NR] * [http://www.statoids.com/unr.html Districts of Nauru], Statoids.com {{ISO 3166}} [[Category:ISO 3166|2:NR]] [[Category:Districts of Nauru|*ISO 3166-2]] [[Category:Nauru-related lists]]

The following is a summary of notable incidents at any of the [[amusement park]]s and [[water park]]s operated by [[Six Flags|Six Flags Entertainment Corporation]]. In some cases, these incidents occurred while the park was under different management or ownership.
This list is not intended to be a comprehensive list of every such event, but only those that have a significant impact on the parks or park operations, or are otherwise significantly noteworthy. The term ''incidents'' refers to major accidents, injuries, or deaths that occur at a park. While these incidents were required to be reported to regulatory authorities due to where they occurred, they usually fall into one of the following categories: # Caused by negligence on the part of the guest. This can be refusal to follow specific ride safety instructions, or deliberate intent to violate park rules. # The result of a guest's known, or unknown, health issues. # Negligence on the part of the park, either by ride operator or maintenance safety instructions, or deliberate intent to violate park rules. # [[Act of God]] or a generic accident (''e.g.'', lightning strike, slipping and falling), that is not a direct result of an action on anybody's part. {{TOC right}}
<!--Do NOT add an incident without an independent third-party source. Per WP:BURDEN, the editor adding the information is responsible for providing the source to back up the change. Fan sites like themeparkreview.com and aggregator sites like rideaccidents.com are not considered reliable, although such sites often link to sources that may meet WP:RS. Personal accounts are not permitted per WP:V and WP:OR.-->
==Great Escape== {{see also|Great Escape (amusement park)}} ===Sky Ride=== * On June 24th, 2017, a 14-year-old girl from [[Greenwood, Delaware]] fell approximately {{convert|25|ft|m|0}} from her gondola, striking a tree before falling to the ground. The girl had slipped under the chair's safety bar while the ride was in motion. The ride was stopped when park visitors alerted the operators to the incident, while other visitors gathered underneath the girl to prepare to catch her. She ultimately fell into the group of visitors below her, with an unidentified 47-year-old man receiving a back injury from the attempt. The passenger received no serious injuries, and was taken to a local hospital. Park officials stated there did not appear to be a malfunction of the ride, but closed the ride pending review.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/six-flags-witness-says-girls-fall-from-ride-was-horrifying/ | title=Six Flags witness says girl's fall from ride was "horrifying" | publisher=CBS | date=2017-06-25 }}</ref>
==La Ronde== {{see also|La Ronde (amusement park)}}
===Le Vampire=== {{main|Le Vampire}} *On July 6, 2012, a 67-year-old employee of the park was killed at ''Le Vampire''. The employee was reportedly found underneath the attraction in a restricted area, appearing to have suffered head trauma. Park officials stated that the employee had been struck by the roller coaster. The employee was pronounced dead at the scene; another individual was taken to a hospital to be treated for shock. Officials with the park did not know why the employee entered the restricted area of the ride while it was operational, but they did state that the ride was operating normally and that procedures for entering restricted ride areas, including notification of ride staff, had not been followed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Worker+dies+Ronde+accident+Montreal/6895065/story.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120708203304/http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Worker+dies+Ronde+accident+Montreal/6895065/story.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-08 |title=Worker dies in La Ronde accident in Montreal |work=MontrealGazette.com |publisher=Postmedia Network |date=2012-07-06 |accessdate=2012-07-07 |df= }}</ref>
==Six Flags America== ===The Joker's Jinx=== {{main|The Joker's Jinx}} *On August 10, 2014, at about 3pm, 24 people were trapped on the roller coaster when the train stalled along the course. The train was upright on a curve near one of the highest points on the ride. The local fire department used an [[Fire_engine#Aerial_apparatus|aerial fire apparatus]] to bring down riders one at a time. By 7:30pm local time, all riders had been removed from the ride, which was immediately closed for investigation. Investigators claim that the stalled train was caused by debris on the track. No riders were injured, and all were evaluated by emergency personnel.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Riders-Stuck-on-Jokers-Jinx-Roller-Coaster-at-Six-Flags-America-270675841.html |title=All Passengers Rescued From Stuck Roller Coaster at Six Flags America |date=2014-08-10 |publisher=News4 }}</ref> *On April 13, 2017, at a little before 6pm, the ride stalled along the same length as the 2014 incident. 24 riders were stuck on the train, and firefighters rescued all the riders with the use of an aerial fire apparatus by 9:20 PM, more than two hours after the park's closing and almost four hours after the train got stuck.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Passengers-Stuck-Upside-Down-on-Prince-Georges-Six-Flags-Roller-Coaster--419427704.html |title=24 People Rescued From Roller Coaster Stuck at Six Flags |date=2017-04-13 |author=Darline Aderoju and Daniel Barnes |publisher=News4 }}</ref>
===Renegade Rapids=== *On June 28, 2000, eight people were trapped when their raft fell off during the ride. All riders escaped but two were injured.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.gazette.net/gazette_archive/2000/200026/landover/news/17131-1.html|title=Park visitors injured on water ride - Gazette.Net|publisher=|date=2000-06-29}}</ref>
===Superman: Ride of Steel=== * On June 18, 2018, 24 passengers were helped off the ride's lift hill after sensors automatically stopped the ride. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Roller-Coaster-Six-Flags-485857281.html |title=Roller Coaster Riders Rescued From Ride at Six Flags in Maryland |date=2018-06-18 |author=NBC Washington Staff |publisher=News4 }}</ref>
===Wave Pool=== *On June 13, 2018, a 14-year-old boy was admitted to the hospital in critical condition after he was rescued from the Wave Pool. Park staff and paramedics treated the boy before he was transported to the hospital. <ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/travel/2018/06/13/teen-who-nearly-drowned-at-six-flags-park-taken-to-hospital-in-critical-condition.html |title=Teen who nearly drowned at Six Flags park taken to hospital in critical condition |date=2018-06-13 |publisher=Fox News Channel |author=Alexandra Deabler}}</ref>
===Park Bomb Scare=== * On July 13, 2016, a bomb threat was called in right before the park opened. The Prince George's County Fire Department bomb squad and security personnel were deployed around the park and found two unattended backpacks that were determined not to be explosive. The all-clear was announced after a search of the park around 2:45 p.m. Six Flags announced that the park would be open until 8 p.m. that evening.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/public-safety/bomb-threat-at-amusement-park-in-prince-georges-county/2016/07/13/2ef2539e-490c-11e6-acbc-4d4870a079da_story.html|title=Six Flags America reopens after bomb threat|author1 =Dana Hedgpeth|author2 =Justin Wm. Moyer |work=The Washington Post|date=2016-07-13|accessdate=2016-07-26}}</ref>
==Six Flags AstroWorld== {{see also|Six Flags AstroWorld}} ===Excalibur=== * On August 9, 1997, a 51-year old maintenance worker was killed after being struck by a roller coaster train. The man was working on a section of track when the train was sent out for a test run and struck him along its way. A signal had indicated to the man that the track was clear.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.sfgate.com/news/article/ROLLER-COASTER-ACCIDENTS-3070456.php|title=Roller Coaster Accidents|author=Associated Press|work=rollercoaster.com|publisher=SFGate|date=1999-08-26|accessdate=2017-08-25}}</ref>
===Texas Cyclone=== * On October 19, 2003, seven people were treated and released from a local hospital after a wooden board fell into the middle of a roller coaster train while the ride was running.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://themeparks.lovetoknow.com/Six_Flags_Accidents|title=Six Flags Accidents|author=Simon Thomas|work=lovetoknow.com|publisher=LoveToKnow|date=2003-10-06|accessdate=2017-08-25}}</ref>
===Mayan Mindbender=== *In 2001, a 13-year-old boy was ejected from the ride due to a faulty lap bar and suffered broken bones in his head, pelvis and legs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.houstonpress.com/news/thrilled-to-death-6586723|title=Thrilled to Death|date=June 3, 2004|accessdate=March 29, 2018}}</ref>
== Darien Lake== *On September 6, 2009, the body of a Pennsylvania man, William Sutherland, who had been reported missing the day before was found in one of the small lakes inside the parking lot. The cause of death was not determined.<ref>{{cite web|title=Missing man's body pulled from water at Darien Lake |url=http://www.buffalonews.com/258/story/786889.html |publisher=The Buffalo News |accessdate=7 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090908011458/http://www.buffalonews.com/258/story/786889.html |archivedate=September 8, 2009 }}</ref> ===Ride of Steel=== * On May 16, 1999, a 37-year-old, 5-foot-6, 365 lb (165 kg) male guest was unable to close his lap bar properly and was ejected and fell approximately {{convert|9|ft|m|0}} from the ''[[Ride of Steel]]'' roller coaster as the ride went over a "camel hump" hill, suffering serious injuries. The victim sued the park and the ride manufacturer [[Intamin]] for negligence, and was awarded US$3.95 million.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.verdictsearch.com/jv3_news/newsletter/nat/052604/3.jsp |title=Theme-park patron ejected from roller coaster |date=2004-03-12 |accessdate=2007-10-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928135146/http://www.verdictsearch.com/jv3_news/newsletter/nat/052604/3.jsp |archivedate=2007-09-28 |df= }}</ref>
* On July 8, 2011, a 29-year-old guest was killed when he was ejected from the ''Ride of Steel'' roller coaster. The rider, an Iraq War veteran whose legs had been amputated, was on the front row of the roller coaster when he was thrown from the train during the course of the ride. Park officials stated that the ride was in proper mechanical order and that the various safety restraints were also working normally at the time of the incident, but that the attraction would remain closed pending an investigation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.9wsyr.com/news/local/story/Iraq-War-vet-dies-on-Darien-Lake-Rollercoaster/jM-zd3jWt0yhuwkx4Y1i4A.cspx|title=Iraq War vet dies on Darien Lake Rollercoaster|work=9WSYR.com|date=2011-07-08|accessdate=2011-07-09}}</ref>
===Silver Bullet=== *On October 1, 2017, a malfunction left cars swinging, injuring a few guests.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.mytwintiers.com/news/local-news/multiple-people-injured-on-silver-bullet-at-darien-lake/821969372|title=Multiple people injured on "Silver Bullet" at Darien Lake|work=mytwintiers.com|date=2017-09-30|accessdate=2017-09-30}}</ref>
==Six Flags Discovery Kingdom== {{see also|Six Flags Discovery Kingdom}}
===Animal attacks=== * On January 5, 1996, two trainers were attacked by [[cougar]]s during an exercise session. One trainer was in the cougar enclosure to take one of the animals for a walk. The cougars, Zuni and Tonto, had been playing among themselves and began aggressively playing with him, causing severe cuts on his face and upper torso. The backup trainer suffered minor cuts and bruises in his attempt to free the other.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1996/01/06/MN52370.DTL&sn=006&sc=305 | title = 2 Marine World Trainers Attacked by Cougars/One man badly clawed, hospitalized | website = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 1996-01-05 | accessdate = 2007-06-04 | first=Stephen C. | last=Garcia}}</ref> * On July 31, 1998, Kuma, a two-year-old [[Bengal tiger]], attacked and seriously injured a guest from [[San Jose, California]], and slightly injured the trainer. The incident happened in a secluded area of the park set up to do private photo sessions with the big cats. The tiger was apparently startled when the guest fell off the photo platform and landed on top of her. The trainer suffered a clawing while trying to free the guest who had received serious injuries to her head and upper torso.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1998/08/01/MN89727.DTL&sn=004&sc=378 | title = Tiger Mauls Woman at Marine World/Trainer also hurt at Vallejo park | website = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 1998-08-01 | accessdate = 2007-06-04 | first1=Patricia | last1=Jacobus | first2=Tanya | last2=Schevitz}}</ref> * On June 2, 2004, a 23-year-old African [[elephant]] named Misha gored her trainer while in her enclosure as the trainer walked beside her. This was Misha's second aggressive act following a previous swipe at a trainer two years prior.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2004/06/02/BAGTD6V9O125.DTL&sn=005&sc=321 | title = Marine World trainer badly hurt by elephant | website = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 2004-06-02 | author=Charlie Goodyear | accessdate = 2008-12-18}}</ref>
===Boomerang=== *On August 25, 1999, 28 passengers were stranded on the [[Boomerang: Coast to Coaster|Boomerang]] ride for several hours. The shuttle that pulled the train up an incline failed to release the train. Employees were eventually able to fix the problem and started the coaster. It successfully went around both loops on its first run, but stalled upside down at the peak of one of the loops on its way back and idled there for many hours. Riders, suffered from cases of severe dehydration and sunburn, were rescued by firefighters in an aerial fire apparatus.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1999/09/04/MN44844.DTL | title = Bad Cable Blamed in Marine World Ride Failure | website = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 1999-09-04 | accessdate = 2012-01-24 }}</ref>
===Monkey Business=== *On August 16, 2001, a 42-year-old woman suffered brain hemorrhage after riding the attraction and died at a hospital two days later from her injuries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.articles.latimes.com/2001/aug/16/local/me-34945|title=Woman Dies After Riding Park Attraction - latimes|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=2001-08-16|accessdate=2018-09-05}}</ref>
===Scat-a-bout=== *On September 4, 1999, a nine-year-old boy was injured when he slipped below the restraining bar on the Scat-a-bout, a [[Twist (ride)|twister ride]]. The boy was thrown from the ride and landed in a nearby planter, receiving cuts on his legs.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/e/a/1999/09/06/METRO279.dtl&sn=027&sc=172 | title = Bay area datelines | website = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 1999-09-06 | accessdate = 2007-07-04 }}</ref> The park later stated that the accident was the result of the boy intentionally sliding beneath the safety restraint.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1999/09/07/MN100100.DTL&sn=024&sc=442 | title = Marine World Says 9-Year-Old Boy at Fault for Fall From Ride | website = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 1999-09-07 | accessdate = 2007-07-04 | first=Henry K. | last=Lee }}</ref>
===Starfish=== * In May 2001, a 41-year-old woman from [[Antioch, California]] was thrown from the ride when a restraining bar failed as the result of a [[Pneumatics|pneumatic]] valve being incorrectly installed. She landed on the pavement and suffered head and knee injuries. Her later lawsuit named both the park and ride manufacturer [[Chance Rides]] as responsible parties.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2002/06/11/BA196338.DTL&sn=008&sc=687 | title = Previous accident blamed on valve / Marine World's 'Starfish' shut down | website = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 2002-06-11 | accessdate = 2007-07-04 | first=Charlie | last=Goodyear }}</ref> * On June 8, 2002, a 4-year-old girl was critically injured when she slipped beneath the restraining bar and fell from the Starfish ride while riding with her mother, receiving critical head injuries.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2002/06/09/MN195105.DTL&sn=012&sc=575 | title = Girl hurt in fall off Marine World ride | website = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 2002-06-09 | accessdate = 2007-07-04 | first=Tyche | last=Hendricks}}</ref> Investigators later blamed park employees for incorrectly seating the girl and not having proper signage indicating the proper seating arrangement for a larger and smaller rider.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2002/08/24/BA217283.DTL&sn=018&sc=499 | title = Marine World blamed in girl's accident/4-year-old wasn't seated correctly, sign not posted at ride, report concludes | website = San Francisco Chronicle | date = 2002-08-24 | accessdate = 2007-07-04 | first=Charlie | last=Goodyear }}</ref>
==Six Flags Elitch Gardens== {{For|incidents at the former Six Flags Elitch Gardens|Incidents at CNL Income Properties parks#Elitch Gardens}}
==Six Flags Fiesta Texas== {{see also|Six Flags Fiesta Texas}} *On July 8, 2000, seven people were injured after a chlorine spill. They were all taken to local hospitals and released without any serious injuries.<ref>RideAccidents.com</ref> ===Guest altercations=== *On July 11, 2007, a 37-year-old man was charged with improper photography and recording after allegedly acting suspiciously with a video camera by secretly filming young girls in the water park section. Reports have said he was trying to film someone without permission in an attempt to arouse or gratify the sexual desire of a person.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.woai.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=a465cd05-9aa9-4cac-822a-3ce541988266 | archive-url=https://archive.is/20071222190457/http://www.woai.com/news/local/story.aspx?content_id=a465cd05-9aa9-4cac-822a-3ce541988266 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2007-12-22 | title = Man Accused of Taping Girls at Water Park | publisher = WOAI | date = 2004-07-12 | accessdate = 2007-07-12}} </ref> ===Boomerang: Coast To Coaster=== *On June 4, 2008, passengers had to evacuate when the ride got stuck mid-ride for one hour.{{Citation needed||date=June 2018}}
===Poltergeist=== * On June 12, 2007, a 14-year-old girl was paralyzed after she fell into a gap between the roller coaster's cars, landing on a concrete floor about {{convert|10|ft|m|0}} below the platform. Family members stated that she may have fainted due to the heat of the day.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/metropolitan/6500993.html|title=Hidden summer danger: Theme parks and carnivals are not following the law on reporting of bad injuries|author=John Tedesco|newspaper=San Antonio Express-News|date=2009-06-27|accessdate=2011-07-11}}</ref> * On August 28, 2010, two people were stuck on the Poltergeist for two hours.<ref>[http://www.woai.com/news/local/story/Two-stuck-on-Fiesta-Texas-roller-coaster-for-two/zYmfNj2wnk2fEbJi_73dxQ.cspx] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100901104537/http://www.woai.com/news/local/story/Two-stuck-on-Fiesta-Texas-roller-coaster-for-two/zYmfNj2wnk2fEbJi_73dxQ.cspx|date=September 1, 2010}}</ref>
==Six Flags Great Adventure== {{see also|Six Flags Great Adventure|Rolling Thunder (roller coaster)|Haunted Castle (Six Flags Great Adventure)}}
===The Chiller=== * In May 2004, the ride malfunctioned when one of the ride's 200 electric motors began smoking. The ride was shut down for 45 minutes<ref name="chiller2004"/> * On August 18, 2004, lightning struck a [[power substation]] near the park, causing a power cut to the park. Twenty passengers on The Chiller were left stranded on the ride, approximately {{convert|75|ft|m}} above ground, for 40 minutes. The train's angle was such that eight passengers were upside-down. No injuries were reported. Only the Robin side was operational at the time of the incident. <ref name="chiller2004">{{cite news | website=The New York Times | date=2004-08-19 | accessdate=2009-04-20 | title=Stalled Coaster Strands 20, Some of Them Upside Down | author=Thomas J Lueck |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/19/nyregion/stalled-coaster-strands-20-some-of-them-upside-down.html }}</ref>
===Guest altercations=== *On April 19, 1987, an unidentified gunman fired several shots into a crowd on the plaza inside the main gate, wounding one man and sending panicked guests running for safety. It was the third violent incident of the day, following two earlier unrelated stabbings. The park was evacuated a few minutes after the shooting, about an hour earlier than its scheduled 8:00 p.m. closing time.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/04/20/nyregion/gunman-fires-into-a-crowd-at-jersey-park.html | title = Gunman fires into a crowd at jersey park | website = The New York Times | date = 1987-04-19 | accessdate = 2009-07-11 | first=James | last=Barron }}</ref> Park officials modified security after the incident, including adding metal detectors at the park's entrance.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PI&s_site=philly&p_multi=PI&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB29C8FD40663F6&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | website=The Philadelphia Inquirer | date=1987-04-21 | title=Park Reviews Security In Wake Of Violence}}</ref>
===Haunted Castle=== *On May 11, 1984, eight teenage visitors were trapped in the [[Haunted Castle (Six Flags Great Adventure)|Haunted Castle]] attraction, and died when it was destroyed by fire. Six Flags Great Adventure and its parent company [[Six Flags]] were subsequently indicted for [[Aggravation (law)|aggravated]] [[manslaughter]], accused of [[Recklessness (psychology)|recklessly]] causing the deaths by taking inadequate precautions against a fire. In the subsequent trial, the prosecution argued that repeated warnings by safety consultants to install sprinklers or smoke alarms had been ignored. The defendants denied any culpability, and contended that the fire was [[arson]] and that no precautions would have saved lives. The trial jury found the defendants not guilty.<ref name="COSTAL">{{cite news|url=http://www.hauntedattraction.com/33/industry.html#ind2 |title=Fire at the Haunted Castle (excerpted from ''Amusement Park Crisis Management'') |publisher=Haunted Attraction Magazine |accessdate=2008-09-21 |author=Joe Costal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061018013158/http://www.hauntedattraction.com/33/industry.html#ind2 |archivedate=October 18, 2006 }}</ref> A light bulb had burned out in one of the rooms of the attraction, and a 14-year-old boy lit a cigarette lighter to find his way through the darkness. The flame ignited some foam rubber padding which was used to protect people from bumping into a wall. A fire resulted, which quickly spread throughout the 17-trailer structure with the help of extremely flammable building materials. The fire eventually engulfed and totally destroyed the attraction.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.rideaccidents.com/rides.html|title=Amusement Ride Fatalities (1972–1997)|website=www.rideaccidents.com|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref>
===The Joker=== * In June 2016, a Philadelphia man received multiple injuries to his foot and knee while riding, when his leg struck a bar attached to the coaster. The victim sued the park for negligence in May 2018.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.courierpostonline.com/story/news/local/south-jersey/2018/05/04/great-adventure-lawsuit-joker-roller-coaster/581559002/ |date=2018-05-04 |publisher=Courier Post |author=Jim Walsh |title=Lawsuit: Roller-coaster ride exceeded 'illusion' of danger }}</ref>
===Lightnin' Loops=== *On June 17, 1987, a 19-year-old woman was killed after falling from the Lightnin' Loops shuttle loop roller coaster.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE5DB113BF93BA25755C0A961948260 | title = Rider on Roller Coaster Dies In a Fall at Great Adventure | website = The New York Times | date = 1987-06-18 | accessdate = 2006-07-29 }}</ref> An investigation by the State Labor Department concluded that the ride itself was operating properly, but that the ride operator started the ride without checking that all of the passengers were securely fastened by the safety harnesses. The Department's Office of Safety Compliance further concluded that the accident would not have occurred if proper procedures had been followed. The park was found to be in violation of the Carnival/Amusement Ride Safety Act and was subsequently charged with the maximum state fine of $1,000.
===Rolling Thunder=== *On August 16, 1981, a 20-year-old park employee from [[Middletown Township, New Jersey]] fell to his death from the Rolling Thunder roller coaster during a routine test run. An investigation by the New Jersey Labor Department concluded that the man may not have secured himself with the safety bar. A park representative later confirmed this conclusion, saying that the employee "may have assumed an unauthorized riding position that did not make use of safety restraints." The ride was inspected, and the Labor Department concluded that the ride was "operationally and mechanically sound."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D04E5D8153BF93BA2575BC0A967948260 | title = Ride in Jersey Park Opens After Death | website = The New York Times | date = 1981-08-18 | accessdate = 2006-07-28 }} </ref>
===Sky Screamer=== * On June 3, 2018, 32 passengers were stuck on the ride for 15 minutes when the attraction stopped at about its mid-point due to safety sensors detecting an error and applying an emergency brake. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nj.com/ocean/index.ssf/2018/06/six_flags_skyscreamer_gets_briefly_stuck.html |title=Six Flags' SkyScreamer strands parkgoers in the air |publisher=NJ.com |author=Jeff Goldman |date=2018-06-04 }}</ref> * On November 11, 2018, guests were stranded about 120 feet in the air for nine minutes when safety sensors detected an error and shut the ride down. No injuries were reported.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://newjersey.news12.com/story/39469185/six-flags-ride-breaks-stranding-patrons-in-the-air |publisher=News 12 |title=Six Flags ride breaks, stranding patrons in the air |date=2018-11-13 }}</ref>
==Six Flags Great America== {{see also|Six Flags Great America|Cajun Cliffhanger|American Eagle (roller coaster)|Ragin' Cajun (roller coaster)|Demon (roller coaster) |Raging Bull (roller coaster) |Whizzer (roller coaster) |Viper (Six Flags Great America) |Spacely's Sprocket Rockets}}
From 2004 to September 2007, the [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration]] (OSHA) inspected Six Flags parks five different times and found a total of four violations. On September 10, 2007, OSHA cited Great America with 38 safety violations, alleging "multiple serious and repeat violations at the amusement park, ranging from defective emergency brakes on an industrial truck to a lack of labeling procedures for preventing inadvertent machine start-ups." OSHA fined the park US$117,700.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailyherald.com/story/?id=34947 | title = OSHA cites Six Flags with 38 safety violations | publisher = Daily Herald | date = 2007-09-10 | accessdate = 2007-09-14 }}</ref>
===Cajun Cliffhanger=== *On July 19, 2000, a 12-year-old girl from [[McHenry, Illinois]] suffered two crushed toes after the floor of the ride was improperly raised prior to the ride coming to a complete stop. A second guest also had her foot trapped in this accident. The ride was permanently shut down as part of an out-of-court settlement. In the ten years prior to this accident, there were thirteen other reported incidents involving the Cajun Cliffhanger ride, at least six of which involved injuries.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nbc5.com/news/1335200/detail.html | title = 'Cajun Cliffhanger' Shut Down In Legal Settlement | publisher = WMAQ | date = 2002-03-28 | accessdate = 2007-06-22 }}</ref>
===Demon=== *On April 18, 1998, 23 riders on the [[Demon (roller coaster)|Demon]] roller coaster were stranded upside-down in the middle of the ride's second vertical loop. Firefighters used an aerial fire apparatus to bring riders to safety, although some were on the ride for as long as three hours. The incident was the result of a mechanical failure.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=28824963&sid=1&Fmt=3&clientId=1452&RQT=309&VName=PQD | title = Accident Blamed on Axle Flaw | website = Chicago Tribune | date = 1998-04-21 | accessdate = 2006-09-26 }}</ref>
===The Edge=== *On May 22, 1984, three teenage boys were seriously injured when the ride vehicle fell back down the lift shaft.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.library.ca.gov/CRB/97/12/97012aa.html | title = Evolution of california's amusement rides safety laws | publisher = California Research Bureau, California State Library | date = 1997-08-01 | accessdate = 2006-12-21 }}</ref>
===Hurricane Harbor=== *On June 29, 2005, a 68-year-old guest from [[Chicago, Illinois]], had a heart attack and died in the wave pool.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-1581181.html | title = Chicago man dies at water park | website = Chicago Sun-Times | date = 2005-06-30 | accessdate = 2010-05-03 }}</ref>
===Ragin' Cajun=== *On May 29, 2004, a 52-year-old ride mechanic from [[Zion, Illinois]], was killed by a roller-coaster car as he attempted to cross the tracks. Suffering from a traumatic head injury, he died at [[Froedtert Hospital]] in [[Milwaukee]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.themilwaukeechannel.com/news/3430456/detail.html |title=Great America Employee Dies of Ride Injuries |publisher=WISN |date=2004-05-18 |accessdate=2006-12-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050331022940/http://www.themilwaukeechannel.com/news/3430456/detail.html |archivedate=March 31, 2005 }}</ref>
===Raging Bull=== * On May 3, 2003, an 11-year-old girl from [[Gary, Indiana]], collapsed after riding the Raging Bull coaster while on a trip with her sisters, cousins and aunt. She died after being taken to the hospital. While initial reports said that she died from choking on [[chewing gum]] she had been chewing while on the ride, the coroner's report later stated that she died due to [[cardiomegaly]], and had been seeing a [[Cardiology|cardiologist]] for treatment.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://abclocal.go.com/wls/story?section=News&id=899641 | title = Girl's death at Six Flags blamed on heart condition | publisher = ABC 7 | date = 2005-12-05 | accessdate = 2006-12-18 }}</ref>
===Sky Trek Tower=== *On June 21, 2015, the ride stopped in the middle of the tower. Guests were stranded for two hours and had to be evacuated down a staircase. No injuries occurred.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/lake-county-news-sun/news/ct-lns-six-flags-roller-coaster-0623-20150622-story.html|title=Sky Trek Tower at Great America temporarily closed after being stuck on Sunday – Lake County News-Sun|author=Chicago Tribune|date=22 June 2015|work=Lake County News-Sun}}</ref>
===Spacely's Sprocket Rockets=== *On August 16, 2006, a 10-year-old girl from [[Arlington Heights, Illinois]], collapsed and died after riding the Spacely's Sprocket Rockets roller coaster in the Camp Cartoon Network area. An [[autopsy]] showed that she died of a [[congenital heart anomaly]]. Her family said that she had a history of the anomaly.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://cbs2chicago.com/nationalhealth/health_story_229082041.html |title=Girl Dies After Collapsing At Six Flags |publisher=CBS 2 |date=2006-08-17 |accessdate=2006-12-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070427113541/http://cbs2chicago.com/nationalhealth/health_story_229082041.html |archivedate=2007-04-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Superman: Ultimate Flight=== *On September 9th, 2017, a 50-year-old man from [[Andersonville, Indiana]] died after riding the flying roller coaster. Exiting the attraction, the man complained of feeling sick, then collapsed on the ramp. He was taken to a nearby hospital, where he later died from what was termed a "natural death".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edgevillebuzz.com/news/andersonville-man-dies-riding-six-flags-extreme-coaster|title=Andersonville Man Dies After Riding Six Flags 'Extreme' Roller Coaster|author=Edgeville Buzz|date=13 September 2017|work=Edgeville Buzz}}</ref>
===Viper=== *On June 25, 1997, a 14-year-old Waukegan boy injured his arm while dangling it outside the car. His limb got caught between the car and the platform as the ride reentered the station and slowed to a stop.<ref>{{cite news | website = Chicago Tribune | date = 1997-06-25 |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1997-06-25/news/9706250328_1_roller-coaster-viper-ride | title = Thrill Park Says Teen Caused Accident | accessdate = 2010-07-14 | first=Andrew| last=Buchanan }}</ref>
===Whizzer=== *During a 1980 investigation of an [[Incidents at Cedar Fair parks#Great America|accident at the Great America park in California]] of their Willard's Whizzer coaster, the [[U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission]] discovered two incidents at the Illinois park that had not been previously reported: on July 24, 1976, 13 guests were injured; and on August 18, 1976, 18 guests were injured. The CPSC report does not list injury or accident details for either incident.<ref>{{cite news |publisher=U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission |date=1980-08-29 |url=http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PREREL/prhtml80/80032.html |title=Commission Files Complaints Following Fatal Accidents On Amusement Park Rides |accessdate=2007-06-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815105458/http://www.cpsc.gov/CPSCPUB/PREREL/prhtml80/80032.html |archivedate=2007-08-15 |df= }}</ref>
==Six Flags Kentucky Kingdom== {{For|incidents at the former Six Flags Kentucky Kingdom|List of incidents at independent amusement parks#Kentucky Kingdom}}
==Six Flags Magic Mountain== {{see also|Six Flags Magic Mountain|Colossus (Six Flags Magic Mountain)|Goliath (Six Flags Magic Mountain)|Ninja (Six Flags Magic Mountain)|Revolution (Six Flags Magic Mountain)|Scream (roller coaster)}}
*In 2006, there were 109 complaints by Magic Mountain guests due to various incidents, according to an annual report from the [[Amusement Safety Organization]]. Reports ranged from nosebleeds and heat exhaustion, to neck and back injuries from various rides. Included in those 109 complaints were 18 reports of people blacking out on the Goliath roller coaster. Other complaints were safety-related, such as notices of ride operators talking on cell phones while operating rides. The report stated that the state of California received notice of 80 injuries at Magic Mountain between January 2001 and December 2006.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://abclocal.go.com/kabc/story?section=local&id=5183800 | title = How Safe Are The Rides At Magic Mountain? | publisher = KABC-TV Los Angeles, CA | date = 2007-04-04 | accessdate = 2007-04-11 }}</ref>
===Colossus=== *In 1978, a 20-year-old woman died after falling out of the ride.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.redlandsdailyfacts.com/lifestyle/20140604/magic-mountains-colossus-slated-for-shutdown-mourned-by-fans |date = 2014-06-04 |publisher = Los Angeles Daily News |author = Susan Abram |title = Magic Mountain’s Colossus, slated for shutdown, mourned by fans |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140607005152/http://www.redlandsdailyfacts.com/lifestyle/20140604/magic-mountains-colossus-slated-for-shutdown-mourned-by-fans |archivedate = 2014-06-07 |df = }}</ref> The lap bar was locked in place but it proved to be ineffective, due to the woman's obesity.<ref>{{cite web|first= Leon |last=Worden |year=2012 |url=http://www.scvhistory.com/scvhistory/sr9617.htm |title=SR9617 | Magic Mountain | Eagles Flight |publisher=Scvhistory.com |accessdate=2013-07-20}}</ref> One of the old cars has been sent to the Sky Tower.<ref name="lamotte">{{cite news |url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=16697568&sid=5&Fmt=3&clientId=1452&RQT=309&VName=PQD | title = Roller Coaster Worker Dies at Magic Mountain | work= Los Angeles Times | date = 1996-05-31 | accessdate = 2006-09-26 }}</ref> This incident prompted Colossus to be closed for a year while the trains were switched out and other adjustments were made. *On September 8, 2014, a fire broke out atop Colossus's lift hill. The ride had already been closed down for conversion into Twisted Colossus, and no injuries or deaths were reported. The fire was caused by welders working on removing track. The fire was an accident, and no one was taken to court.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://time.com/3307029/six-flags-iconic-colossus-roller-coaster-catches-fire-portion-collapses/ | date=2014-09-08 | publisher=Time | author=Rishi Iyengar | title=Six Flags’ Iconic Colossus Roller Coaster Catches Fire, Portion Collapses}}</ref>
===Eagle's Flight=== *On February 5, 1978, a gondola car on Eagle's Flight traveling the Galaxy course fell {{convert|50|ft}} to the ground. A pair of newlyweds were violently rocking the car back and forth, causing it to detach from the cable. The husband was killed, and his wife suffered serious injuries, including losing her legs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rideaccidents.com/rides.html|title = U.S. Amusement Ride Fatalities (1972–1997)|accessdate = 2009-05-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scvhistory.com/scvhistory/sr9602.htm|title = Magic Mountain Construction, 1969}}</ref>
===Goliath=== *On June 2, 2001, a 28-year-old woman died of a [[Intracranial aneurysm|brain aneurysm]] while riding Goliath. Her family sued the park, claiming that managers were aware of other complaints from Goliath riders and continued to operate the coaster anyway.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/may/23/local/me-roller23 | title = Family Sues Amusement Park Owner Over Death | website = Los Angeles Times | date = 2002-05-23 | accessdate = 2011-01-15 }}</ref> *On April 4, 2015, one of Goliath's trains got stuck on the lift hill during a test run due to a chain malfunction which needed an entire chain replacement. The train was eventually brought down and the ride remained closed until the lift hill was fixed. The ride eventually reopened on July 18, 2015.
===Hurricane Harbor=== *On September 30, 2012, a 19-year-old man fell from the Venom Drop water slide. According to a spokesperson for the water park, the man cut in line at the slide, fought through the lifeguards, and jumped onto the slide head-first. The man tumbled onto the slide and slipped over the edge, falling {{convert|60|ft|m|0}} onto a fence below the slide tower. The local sheriff's office reported that the man was transported to an area hospital with life-threatening injuries.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://abclocal.go.com/kabc/story?section=news/local/los_angeles&id=8830704 | title = Hurricane Harbor accident: Man falls off Black Snake Summit slide | publisher = KABC-TV Los Angeles, CA | date = 2012-09-30 | accessdate = 2012-10-01 }}</ref>
===Ninja=== *On August 30, 2008, a 20-year-old man was hospitalized after being hit by the train and knocked unconscious when he allegedly climbed multiple security fences to retrieve a hat. Airlifted to the [[UCLA Medical Center]], he was pronounced dead at 2 a.m. on the following day, due to blunt force trauma.<ref>{{cite news |agency=Associated Press |title=Man struck by roller coaster at Magic Mountain |date=2008-09-03 |accessdate=2008-09-04 |url=http://www.dailynews.com/ci_10375320 |work=Los Angeles Daily News |publisher=Los Angeles Newspaper Group |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907123727/http://www.dailynews.com/ci_10375320 |archivedate=2008-09-07 |df= }}</ref> *On July 7, 2014, 22 guests were stranded for over two hours after a tree branch fell onto the coaster track. Four of the 22 guests were injured, but none serious enough to require a hospital visit.<ref>{{cite news | title=Fallen Tree Branch Leaves Riders Stranded at Six Flags Magic Mountain | date=2014-07-07 | accessdate=2014-07-07 |url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/4-Hurt-Riders-Stranded-Ninja-Six-Flags-Magic-Mountain-Ride-266136901.html | author=Willian Avila, Ryan Bourgard}}</ref>
===Revolution=== *On May 30, 1996, an employee was killed while crossing the tracks in the roller coaster's station. She slipped and fell into a shallow pit beneath the tracks and was struck by a train that was pulling into the station.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-06-01/local/me-10714_1_roller-coaster-train | title = Roller Coaster Worker Broke Rule, Officials Say | website = Los Angeles Times | date = 1996-06-01 | accessdate = 2015-06-19 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-05-31/news/mn-10483_1_revolution-roller-coaster | title = Roller Coaster Worker Dies at Magic Mountain | website = Los Angeles Times | date = 1996-05-31 | accessdate = 2015-06-19 }}</ref> *On June 13, 2015, a 10-year-old girl was found unconscious but breathing after returning to the roller coaster's station. She died the following day at a nearby hospital. A coroner's report said the girl died from [[natural causes]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/06/15/us/california-six-flags-roller-coaster-death/ | title = 10-year-old dies after riding roller coaster at Six Flags park in California | work= Los Angeles Times | date = 2015-06-17 | accessdate = 2015-06-19 }}</ref>
===Scream=== *On April 9, 2004, a 21-year-old ride operator died after being struck by the roller coaster while underneath the track during a test run prior to the park's opening that day. The roller coaster was allowed to be re-opened the next week after an [[Occupational Safety and Health Administration|OSHA]] inspection found no mechanical issues.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/apr/10/local/me-killed10 | title = Magic Mountain Employee Fatally Hit by 'Scream' Ride | publisher = L.A. Times | date = 2004-04-10 | accessdate = 2016-01-06 }}</ref>
==Six Flags Mexico== {{see also|Six Flags Mexico}}
*On June 8, 2014, around 10 a.m., a fire broke out in a warehouse of stuffed animals. Injured men and women were evacuated, leaving a 500-meter area affected. It has been established that the cause of the fire was due to a short circuit. At the time of the fire the park was closed.{{Citation needed||date=June 2018}}
==Six Flags New England== {{see also|Six Flags New England|Bizarro (Six Flags New England)|Houdini's Great Escape}}
===Houdini's Great Escape=== * On October 9, 2010, Houdini's Great Escape (which was being used as a haunted house called Midnight Mansion), which was available during Fright Fest, suspiciously caught on fire. Firefighters were called to extinguish the flames, but the ride was closed for the rest of the night and the following day. Investigations showed that a [[flammable]] [[cobweb]] hanging on the top of the building was the cause of the fire after coming in close contact with a light fixture. Nearly {{convert|20|ft|m|0}} of cobweb burned up, and the building only suffered minor damages to the roof and exterior. No one was injured, but damages were estimated at $5,000.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wwlp.com/dpp/news/local/hampden/six-flags-evacuated-after-park-fire |title=Midnight Mansion reopens after fire |publisher=22 News |date=2010-10-09 |accessdate=2010-10-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101012042336/http://www.wwlp.com/dpp/news/local/hampden/six-flags-evacuated-after-park-fire |archivedate=October 12, 2010 }}</ref>
===Superman: The Ride=== * On August 6, 2001, one of the trains failed to stop at the ride's [[brake run]], colliding with the other train in the loading station. 22 people were taken to hospitals, without any major injuries. The ride would reopen twelve days later on August 18, 2001.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2001/US/08/06/roller.coaster.crash/index.html|title=CNN.com - 21 injured in Six Flags coaster accident - August 6, 2001|publisher=CNN|date=2001-08-06}}</ref> * On May 1, 2004, a 55-year-old, 5-foot-2, 230 lb (104.5 kg) man from [[Bloomfield, Connecticut]] fell out of his coaster seat during the last turn and was killed. Reports show that the ride attendant had not checked that the guest's ride restraint was secure<ref>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E06EED9143CF93BA35756C0A9629C8B63 | title = New England: Massachusetts: Coaster Death Report | website = The New York Times | date = 2004-05-08 | accessdate = 2006-07-31 }}</ref> as his girth was too large for the T-bar-shaped ride restraint to close properly. The victim's family said that due to his various medical conditions, such as [[cerebral palsy]], he shouldn't have been allowed to ride. The park stated that the federal [[Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990|Americans with Disabilities Act]] forbids them from denying a ride to a person with a disability as long as the person can get on the ride by themselves.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nbc30.com/news/3260041/detail.html | title = Investigators Preparing Report in Roller Coaster Death | publisher = NBC30.com | date = 2004-05-04 | accessdate = 2006-07-31 }}</ref>
===Blizzard River=== *On August 7th, 1999, a raft carrying six people flipped, trapping some riders under water. All six riders were injured.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.articles.courant.com/2001-07-21/news/0107210168_1_premier-parks-ride-six-flags-new-england |title=Eight Trapped in Water Ride Sue Amusement Park - tribunedigital-thecourant |publisher= Hartford Courant |date= 2001-07-21 |accessdate= 2018-09-22}}</ref>
==Six Flags New Orleans== {{main|Six Flags New Orleans}}
===Joker's Jukebox=== *On July 10, 2003, a 52-year-old grandmother was strapping her 4-year-old grandson in when the ride started up. She died from blunt-force internal injuries after being struck by a ride vehicle.<ref>{{cite news |title=Woman Killed In Accident At Six Flags |date=2003-07-11 |publisher=WDSU 6 |url=http://www.wdsu.com/news/2323659/detail.html |accessdate=2008-06-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060427035921/http://www.wdsu.com/news/2323659/detail.html |archivedate=April 27, 2006 }}</ref> The park added mirrors to the ride for ride operators to view around the blind spot where the accident occurred, and then introduced a safety announcement which notified the guests that the ride was about to start.
==Six Flags Over Georgia== {{see also|Six Flags Over Georgia|Goliath (Six Flags Over Georgia)|Mind Bender (Six Flags Over Georgia)}}
===Batman: The Ride=== * On May 26, 2002, a 58-year-old Six Flags foreman was struck in the head and killed by the dangling legs of a passenger after he wandered into the ride's path after entering a locked, no-access area during the ride's operation. The passenger, a 14-year-old girl, was hospitalized with leg injuries and released.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QHUVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qOsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6724,7572014&dq=six+flags+employee+was+struck+in+the+head |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130124132911/http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QHUVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qOsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6724,7572014&dq=six+flags+employee+was+struck+in+the+head |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-24 | title = Theme park foreman dies in freak accident | publisher = Eugene Register-Guard | date = 2002-05-28 | accessdate = 2009-08-16 }} </ref> * On June 28, 2008, a 17-year-old male from [[Springfield, South Carolina]] was [[decapitation|decapitated]] by the passing train after he climbed over two six-foot fences and entered a restricted area. Reports said that the victim was trying to retrieve his lost hat.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cnn.com/2008/US/06/28/theme.park.fatality/index.html?iref=newssearch|title = Teen struck, killed by coaster at theme park, police say|date = 28 June 2008|accessdate = 2 February 2015|website = CNN|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Additional eyewitnesses stated that the victim and a companion, who also entered the restricted area but was uninjured, were trying to take a shortcut back into the park after leaving the park for lunch.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.fitsnews.com/2008/06/30/south-carolina-teen-decapitated-by-batman-ride/|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080703041242/http://www.fitsnews.com/2008/06/30/south-carolina-teen-decapitated-by-batman-ride/|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 3 July 2008|title = South Carolina Teen Decapitated By Batman Ride|date = 30 June 2008|accessdate = 2 February 2015|website = Fitsnews|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
===Goliath=== *On July 27, 2006, a 45-year-old male from [[Birmingham, Alabama]], died of a heart attack after riding Goliath. He was alert during the ride but was unconscious when the train arrived at the loading platform. An autopsy showed that the man had a congenital heart condition, and it was expected that the medical examiner would announce that he died of natural causes.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.macon.com/mld/macon/news/politics/15147522.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130128061930/http://www.macon.com/mld/macon/news/politics/15147522.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-28 | title = Man dies after riding the roller coaster at Six Flags | publisher = Macon Telegraph | date = 2006-07-28 | accessdate = 2006-07-28 }} </ref> Goliath was closed for two hours for an inspection, but was found to be operating normally.
===Great Air Racer=== *On May 27, 1984, four passengers were injured after a computer malfunction caused the ride's cables to drop the planes out of position.<ref name="4InjSFOG">{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940CE6D6153BF936A35755C0A962948260&n=Top%2fReference%2fTimes%20Topics%2fSubjects%2fA%2fAmusement%20and%20Theme%20Parks | title = 4 Injured on Six Flags Ride | website = The New York Times | date = 1984-06-05 | accessdate = 2006-07-28 }}</ref>
===Six Flags Railroad=== * On May 13, 2018, the train engine caught fire. Two employees were taken to the hospital, and while no park guests were on the ride at the time of the accident, one park guest was treated at a local hospital.<ref> {{cite news |url=https://www.ajc.com/news/local/fire-six-flags-over-georgia-ride-sends-two-employees-hospital-video/19SQDWNK0yi4Tv0tJxT1EL/ |title=Fire on Six Flags Over Georgia ride sends two employees to the hospital |publisher=AJC |date=2018-05-13 |accessdate=2018-05-15 }}</ref>
===Mind Bender=== *On June 3, 1984, a mechanical problem caused a train to stop abruptly, causing four people to be hospitalized. The ride was repaired and put back into service with no more problems.<ref name="4InjSFOG"/>
===Wheelie=== *In May 2009, four children became ill when the attraction failed to stop at the end of its cycle. After returning to a horizontal position, a [[limit switch]] failed and the ride continued to spin for five to ten minutes. The park's first-aid staff treated the children, while one was transported to an area hospital by his parents; the child was not admitted, however. An investigation determined that the ride operator did not engage an emergency stop switch due to a miscommunication between her and her supervisor; the park's ride operators are trained in how to stop their rides in the event of a malfunction. Since then, additional safety features have been added to ensure that the attraction automatically stops within 15 seconds if the limit switch were to fail.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ajc.com/news/regulators-monitor-amusement-rides-171756.html | title=Regulators monitor amusement rides | author=Alison Young | work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution | accessdate=2009-10-25}}</ref>
===Z-Force=== *On July 18, 1989, an 11-year-old boy from [[Talladega, Alabama]], became unconscious while riding Z-Force. Park staff performed CPR, but the victim was pronounced dead after being taken to the hospital.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ |title = 11-year-old boy dies after 'z-force' roller coaster ride |publisher = San Jose Mercury News (CA) / Article ID 8902270054 |date = 1989-07-19 |accessdate = 2008-07-02 }}</ref> An autopsy failed to pinpoint the cause of death.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SJ&s_site=mercurynews&p_multi=SJ&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB7306116C7F11C&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title = Roller-coaster death |publisher = ''The Mercury News'' (CA) |date = 1989-07-20 |accessdate = 2008-07-02 }}</ref>
==Six Flags Over Texas== {{see also|Six Flags Over Texas}}
===The Joker=== *In the early hours of May 20, 2017, eight passengers were stuck for several hours when heavy winds caused their car to stall out on the top section of the track. Fire department crews assisted in rescuing the riders about three hours after the stoppage. No injuries were reported. The park inspected the ride and re-opened it to the public on May 21.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/arlington/2017/05/20/passengers-stuck-hours-overnight-six-flags-texas-roller-coaster|title=Trapped teens on Six Flags roller coaster thought they 'were going to die'|author=Liz Farmer| work=The Dallas Morning News|date=May 21, 2017|accessdate=May 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/SixFlagsOverTX/status/866338828298137600|title=Six Flags Over Texas on Twitter|work=twitter.com|date=May 21, 2017|accessdate=May 22, 2017}}</ref>
===Roaring Rapids=== *On March 21, 1999, a 28-year-old Arkansas woman died, and 10 other guests were injured, when the raft they were on overturned in 2–3 feet of water due to sudden deflation of the air chambers that support the raft. The raft then became caught on an underwater pipe, which provided leverage for the rushing water in the ride to flip the boat over.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://web.caller.com/autoconv/newstexmex99/newstexmex235.html |title='Unimaginable' events led to accident, officials say |publisher=Corpus Christi Online |date=1999-04-21 |accessdate=2006-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708112052/http://web.caller.com/autoconv/newstexmex99/newstexmex235.html |archivedate=July 8, 2011 }}</ref> In a subsequent settlement, Six Flags agreed to pay US$4 million to the victim's family, and the company said it would join the family in a lawsuit against Canyon Manufacturing Co., the company responsible for parts that were related to the accident.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.texnews.com/1998/2002/texas/six0223.html |title=Six Flags to pay millions to victim's kin |agency=Associated Press |date=2002-02-23 |accessdate=2006-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215004111/http://www.texnews.com/1998/2002/texas/six0223.html |archivedate=2012-02-15 |df= }}</ref>
===New Texas Giant=== {{Main article|New Texas Giant}} *On July 19, 2013, a 52-year-old woman from [[Dallas, Texas]], fell {{Convert|75|ft|m}} to her death while riding the [[New Texas Giant]] roller coaster.<ref name="fall">{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/07/23/us/texas-roller-coaster-death/index.html?hpt=hp_t2|title=Second coaster closed in Texas amid probe; details emerge on earlier death|first=Michael| last= Martinez | work=CNN.com |date=2013-07-23 |accessdate=2013-07-23}}</ref> According to one eyewitness account, the victim – described as overweight – was concerned about being properly secured after boarding the ride. She heard other restraints click three times but only reported hearing hers click once. A ride attendant assured her that as long as she heard a click, it was secure. Some riders informed investigators that the woman was thrown from the roller coaster as it rounded a turn, and one rider tweeted that he saw the restraint come undone. Other eyewitnesses believed the seat restraint remain locked in the lowered position when the train returned to the station. The ride closed for two months during the investigation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/metro/20130719-breaking-news-arlington-police-fire-at-six-flags-for-fatal-incident-texas-giant-said-to-be-involved.ece|title=Breaking: Woman dies on Six Flags'Texas Giant roller coaster|first=Robert| last= Wilonsky | work=dallasnews.com |date=2013-07-19 |accessdate=2013-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.myfoxdfw.com/story/22889634/six-flags-woman-died-while-riding-texas-giant|title=Six Flags: Woman died while riding Texas Giant |last1=Kretz |first1=Chelsea |last2=Collins|first2=Calvert|date=July 19, 2013|publisher=KDFW FOX 4|accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/flags-texas-witnesses-shocked-roller-coaster-death/story?id=19721888|title=Witnesses on Six Flags Over Texas Roller Coaster Death: 'That Could Have Been Me'|last1=James |first1=Michael |last2=Shaw|first2=Alexis|date=July 20, 2013|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> The victim was found on top of the metal roof of one of the coaster tunnels, near the ''Music Mill Amphitheater''.<ref name="fall"/> Due to its similarity to Texas Giant, [[Iron Rattler]] was closed temporarily by Six Flags Fiesta Texas following the incident.<ref name="fall"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kens5.com/news/Iron-Rattler-remains-closed-as-Six-Flags-investigates-womans-death-216463961.html |title=Iron Rattler remains closed as Six Flags investigates woman's death |date=July 22, 2013 |publisher=KENS |accessdate=July 23, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130722181139/http://www.kens5.com/news/Iron-Rattler-remains-closed-as-Six-Flags-investigates-womans-death-216463961.html |archivedate=July 22, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news4sanantonio.com/news/features/top-stories/stories/fiesta-texas-temporarily-closes-iron-rattler-878.shtml |title=Fiesta Texas temporarily closes Iron Rattler |date=July 22, 2013 |publisher=News4 San Antonio |accessdate=July 23, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130726004959/http://www.news4sanantonio.com/news/features/top-stories/stories/fiesta-texas-temporarily-closes-iron-rattler-878.shtml |archivedate=July 26, 2013 }}</ref> It reopened almost a month later with added seat belts.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kens5.com/news/Six-Flags-adds-seatbelts-to-Iron-Rattler-after-deadly-fall-at-Arlington-park-219794881.html |title=Six Flags adds seat belts to Iron Rattler after deadly fall in Arlington |work=kens.com |date=2013-08-15 |accessdate=2013-08-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130815235258/http://www.kens5.com/news/Six-Flags-adds-seatbelts-to-Iron-Rattler-after-deadly-fall-at-Arlington-park-219794881.html |archivedate=2013-08-15 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ksat.com/news/iron-rattler-reopens-at-fiesta-texas-in-san-antonio/-/478452/21484634/-/4xiymk/-/index.html |title=Iron Rattler reopens at Fiesta Texas in San Antonio |work=ksat.com |last=Ibanez |first=David |date=2013-08-14 |accessdate=2013-08-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140308113020/http://www.ksat.com/news/iron-rattler-reopens-at-fiesta-texas-in-san-antonio/-/478452/21484634/-/4xiymk/-/index.html |archivedate=March 8, 2014 }}</ref> Representatives from [[Gerstlauer]], the German company that designed and built the ride's trains, participated in the investigation.<ref name="Gerst">{{cite web|url=http://www.ajc.com/ap/ap/top-news/womans-six-flags-roller-coaster-death-probed/nYxgk/|title=Company to inspect Texas coaster where woman fell|author=Associated Press|work=ajc.com|publisher=Cox Newspapers, Inc.|date=July 21, 2013|accessdate=July 22, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130723070952/http://www.ajc.com/ap/ap/top-news/womans-six-flags-roller-coaster-death-probed/nYxgk/|archivedate=July 23, 2013}}</ref> While Gerstlauer would not discuss any specifics, they released a statement saying their restraint system could not open while the ride was in motion.<ref name="Gerst"/> The investigation was completed on September 10, 2013, and Texas Giant reopened on September 14, 2013. Each train's restraint system was modified, seat belts were added, and a seat replica was placed at the entrance allowing riders to test before waiting in line.<ref name="reopening">{{cite news|url=http://www.sixflags.com/overtexas/info/texasupdate.aspx |title=The Texas Giant to Re-Open Following Implementation of Incremental Safety Measures |date=September 10, 2013 |publisher=Six Flags Over Texas |accessdate=September 11, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131031093121/http://www.sixflags.com/overtexas/info/texasupdate.aspx |archivedate=October 31, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/09/11/us/texas-roller-coaster-reopens/|title=Texas roller coaster set to reopen after woman's death|last1=Shoichet|first1=Catherine E.|last2=Sutton|first2=Joe|date=September 11, 2013|publisher=CNN|accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> The woman's family filed lawsuits against both the park and manufacturer, both of which blamed and sued each other for the accident.<ref name="wfaa1113">{{cite news|url=http://www.wfaa.com/news/local/tarrant/Six-Flags-accident-investigation-231068981.html |title=Arlington police report details woman's death after fall from Texas Giant |work=WFAA |date=November 7, 2013 |accessdate=July 25, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728051702/http://www.wfaa.com/news/local/tarrant/Six-Flags-accident-investigation-231068981.html |archivedate=July 28, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="dallas214">{{cite news |url=http://www.dallasnews.com/news/local-news/20140217-six-flags-blames-roller-coaster-company-for-fatal-texas-giant-accident.ece | title=Six Flags blames roller coaster company for fatal Texas Giant accident | work=Dallas News | date=February 17, 2014 | accessdate=July 25, 2014 | author=Mosier, Jeff}}</ref> On November 18, 2014, attorneys for the victim's family announced that they had reached an undisclosed settlement with both Six Flags and Gerstlauer, with a spokesperson saying the family "is very pleased with the settlement and appreciates the condolences offered by Six Flags and Gerstlauer".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/family-mom-killed-texas-theme-park-nets-settlement-article-1.2015592|title=Family of mom who fell 75 feet to her death at Texas theme park nets settlement|author=Jason Molinet|work=nydailynews.com|publisher=NYDailyNews.com|date=November 18, 2014|accessdate=November 21, 2014}}</ref>
=== Hurricane Harbor === * On August 9, 2012, six lifeguards suffered minor injuries on the Tornado water slide during a training session. Park officials say it was the result of 'inappropriate horseplay'.<ref name=":0">RideAccidents.com</ref>
===Texas Tornado (Now known as The Gunslinger)=== * On March 12, 2006, ten people suffered minor injuries when the Texas Tornado, a [[Chance Morgan|Chance Rides Manufacturing]] "[[Swing ride|Yo-Yo]]" attraction, was brought to an abrupt stop and several swing seats collided with each other. Five people were sent to the hospital after complaints of back pain, the others were treated at the on-site first aid station.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://cbs11tv.com/local/six.flags.lawsuit.2.677168.html |title=Woman Sues Six Flags Over Ride Mishap |publisher=CBS 11 |date=2008-03-14 |accessdate=2008-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210143949/http://cbs11tv.com/local/six.flags.lawsuit.2.677168.html |archivedate=February 10, 2009 }}</ref> In October 2008, Chance recalled 85 Yo-Yo rides to repair defects that were found in this accident and one other.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://cbs11tv.com/entertainment/gunslinger.ride.recall.2.836392.html |title=Six Flags Over Texas Ride Among Recalled |publisher=CBS 11 |date=2008-10-09 |accessdate=2008-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090210153609/http://cbs11tv.com/entertainment/gunslinger.ride.recall.2.836392.html |archivedate=February 10, 2009 }}</ref>
==Six Flags St. Louis== {{see also|Six Flags St. Louis}} ===Boomerang=== * On May 6, 2016, the Boomerang came to an abrupt halt. The park was closed at the time, but groups of high school students were at the park on field trips. Four students suffered minor injuries, but were able to get off the ride. Three of the students were taken to a nearby hospital as a precautionary measure, though no one was seriously injured.<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/metro/injured-on-six-flags-roller-coaster/article_215592d3-fc42-5b58-ad60-878a66033005.html | title=4 injured when Six Flags roller coaster stops suddenly mid-ride | Metro | stltoday.com | date=May 7, 2016 | access-date=June 24, 2016}}</ref>
===River King Mine Train / Rail Blazer=== *On July 7, 1984, a 46-year-old woman from [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] was riding the [[River King Mine Train|Rail Blazer]] roller coaster when she was flung from the ride and fell {{convert|20|ft|m}} to her death. Park officials claimed that the woman fainted and fell out of the car, but her husband, who had been beside her, said that she had not fainted but had simply been tossed from the ride when it whipped around a curve. At the time, the ride was only the third stand-up roller coaster in the world, but following this incident it was converted back to a sit-down coaster.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=951682791&sid=4&Fmt=3&clientId=1452&RQT=309&VName=PQD | title = Woman Flung to Death From Roller Coaster | website = The New York Times | date = 1984-07-09 | accessdate = 2006-09-26 }}</ref>
===Skyway=== *On July 26, 1978, a man and two of his three nieces who were riding with him died when their gondola fell from the cable.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=951682791&sid=4&Fmt=3&clientId=1452&RQT=309&VName=PQD | title = Three killed after car plunges at Six Flags. | publisher = Post Dispatch | date = 1978-07-26 | accessdate = 2008-06-29 }}</ref> The ride was shut down immediately, leaving nearly 100 people stranded in the 27 remaining cars, some of which had stopped at heights of up to {{convert|200|ft|m|0}}. Firefighters were called to the park to rescue the occupants of those cars. A park spokesman claimed that the car simply "dropped off" its cable.<ref name=":1" />
===Typhoon Twister=== *On June 24, 2018, there were two separate incidents on the attraction - one involving a 27-year-old man from St. Louis,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.myleaderpaper.com/news/accidents/st-louis-man-hurt-on-six-flags-ride-the-same/article_c02c23d6-799c-11e8-8137-4775b4f36451.html |title=St. Louis man hurt on Six Flags ride the same day it opens |publisher=My Leader Paper |date=2018-06-27 |author=Katelyn Mary Skaggs }}</ref> and the other a woman from [[Lebanon, Missouri]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ksdk.com/article/news/local/new-six-flags-ride-typhoon-twister-closed-after-person-injured/63-567052735 |title=New Six Flags ride Typhoon Twister closed after person injured |author=Jenn Sullivan |date=2018-06-24 |publisher=KSDK-TV }}</ref> In both cases, the guests fell out of rafts while riding, and were taken to the hospital due to undisclosed injuries. Park management closed the ride for inspection following the pair of incidents, per standard procedure.
===Guest altercations=== *On June 3, 2018, a 23-year-old man from [[Caseyville, Illinois]] hit and pushed an employee dressed as [[Daffy Duck]]. The guest was arrested by police for assault.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.kmov.com/story/38415050/caseyville-man-assaults-daffy-duck-at-six-flags-eureka-police-say |title=Caseyville man assaults Daffy Duck at Six Flags, Eureka police say |date=2018-06-13 |publisher=KMOV-TV |author=Rachel Sudduth }}</ref>
==Six Flags White Water== {{see also|Six Flags White Water}}
===Hurricane Harbor=== *In March 2016, two individuals broke into the park, went past three fences, and skateboarded down the Tornado water slide as a half pipe. They were arrested on felony charges of criminal damage to property, causing an estimated $20,000 in damages to the fiberglass coat covering the slide.<ref>http://www.northwestgeorgianews.com/police-skateboarders-damage-water-slide/article_beb8bcbb-e0cf-5ad7-9de2-bdc165c7ef00.html </ref>
===Maintenance building=== *On July 11, 2010, a fire broke out in a maintenance building during operating hours, forcing the evacuation and closure of the park. The fire was contained to a single building, located adjacent to the park's wave pool and used principally for storage. Spokespeople for the water park and for the [[Cobb County, Georgia|Cobb County]] fire department noted that everyone was evacuated safely and that there were no reported injuries. The park re-opened two days later on July 13 after crews had sealed off the damaged area caused by the fire.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/after-fire-white-water-568510.html|title=After fire, White Water to reopen Tuesday|author=Alexis Stevens|work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution|date=2010-07-12|accessdate=2010-07-13}}</ref>
==Six Flags Worlds of Adventure== {{For|incidents at the former Six Flags Worlds of Adventure|Incidents at Cedar Fair parks#Geauga Lake}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{Six Flags}} {{Amusement park accidents}}
[[Category:Six Flags]] [[Category:Lists of amusement park incidents|Six Flags]] [[Category:Lists by organization|Six Flags]] [[Category:Death-related lists]] [[Category:Health-related lists]]

revision.comment: Bot: fixing [[WP:CHECKWIKI]] error #37 (no DEFAULTSORT for article with special character)
/* Culture */Added content about the current state of the Ixil culture and added a section about their diet
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=March 2007}} [[File:Nebaj.JPG|right|thumb|150px|Celebrations at Santa Maria Nebaj, 2005]] The '''Ixil Community''' is a name given to three neighbouring towns in the [[Quiché (department)|Quiché department]] in the western highlands of [[Guatemala]].<ref name=refugee>{{Cite book|title=Refugees of a hidden war: the aftermath of counterinsurgency in Guatemala |first=Beatriz |last=Manz |publisher=SUNY Press |year=1988 |page=96 |isbn=978-0-88706-676-4}}</ref> These towns are [[Santa Maria Nebaj]], [[San Juan Cotzal]], and [[Chajul|San Gaspar Chajul]].<ref>Manz, Beatriz (1988) p.97</ref> The area's population is predominantly of [[Ixil people|Ixil]] descent. When viewed on a map, the three Ixil towns appear to form a triangle, because of this, is also named '''Ixil Triangle'''.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Moon Handbooks Guatemala |first=Al |last=Argueta |publisher=Avalon Travel |year=2007 |page=109 |isbn=978-1-59880-057-9}}</ref>
==Culture== Due to its location in the [[Sierra de los Cuchumatanes|Cuchumatanes mountains]],<ref>Argueta, Al (2007) p.150</ref> the Ixil Community has remained isolated from the rest of the world. Its people have therefore maintained their traditional culture — free from influences of the outside world. Although the introduction modern western media is rapidly eroding the culture as young men and women look North for economic prosperity and abandonment of the culture and language are present problems .Most men are farmers, and most women are weavers.
Their diet primarily consists of maze based products. Small round tortillas or corn dumplings known as tamalitos are a staple at almost every meal. This love of corn is ingrined in the culture, so much so that many of the Ixil refer to themselves as "men of corn". Stating that the first humans were rolled from masa or ground up maze.
Other foods commonly eaten are boxbol, which are small corn dumplings steamed in squash leaves covered in chili sauce.
Malanga, "guiscil", beans, squash, and eggs make up the rest of their typical diet.
The people of the Ixil Community primarily speak the [[Ixil language]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Unfinished Conquest: The Guatemalan Tragedy |first=Victor |last=Perera |publisher=University of California Press |year=1995 |page=61 |isbn=978-0-520-20349-5}}</ref> Some villagers speak [[Spanish language|Spanish]] as a secondary language.
==Turmoil During Civil War== {{main|Guatemalan Civil War}}
[[File:Exhumation in the ixil triangle in Guatemala.jpg|thumb|Ixil people carrying their loved one's remains after an exhumation in the Ixil Triangle in February 2012.]] During the [[Guatemalan Civil War]], the [[Guerrilla Army of the Poor]] (EGP) used the surrounding mountains as a base of operations.<ref name=adventure>{{Cite book|title=Adventure Guide to Guatemala |first=Shelagh |last=McNally |publisher=Hunter Publishing, Inc |year=2003 |page=213 |isbn=978-1-58843-347-3}}</ref> The Guatemalan Army pursued a [[scorched-earth]] policy to destroy villages.<ref name=refugee/> The villagers of the Ixil Community were caught in the crossfire, and thousands of civilians were killed, [[torture]]d, or [[Forced disappearance|missing.]]<ref name=adventure/><ref>Argueta, Al (2007) p.151</ref>
The army's campaign against civilians in this region may have been motivated partially by a desire "to weaken and eventually eradicate Maya culture." Villagers slowly learned not to wear their traditional Maya clothing, because its distinctive appearance made them easy targets for soldiers.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==
{{coord missing|Guatemala}}
