revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Marcelino Oreja Elósegui | image = TTV.98.120.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Marcelino Oreja Elósegui | birth_date = 1894 | birth_place = [[Ibarrangelu]] | death_date = 1934 | death_place = [[Mondragón]] | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = civil engineer | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Carlism]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }}
'''Marcelino Oreja Elósegui''' (1894 - 1934) was a Spanish [[entrepreneur]], Catholic activist and [[Carlism|Carlist]] politician.
==Family and youth== [[File:Ibarranguelua.JPG|thumbnail|left|Ibarrangelu]] Marcelino Oreja Elósegui was descendant to a petty [[bourgeoisie]] [[Basque people|Basque]] family, originating from the [[Gipuzkoa]]n town of [[Orexa]].<ref>according to Marcelino Oreja Aguirre, ''Antecedentes de la Revolución de octubre de 1934 y su repercusión en el País Vasco'', [in:] ''Euskonews'' s/d, available [http://www.euskonews.com/0600zbk/gaia60001es.html here]; José María Urkia Etxabe, ''Benigno Oreja, pionero de la Urología en Euskadi'', [in:] ''Noticias de Gipuzkoa'', 15.10.14 claims that the family was from “localidades navarras de Atayo y Arriba” see [http://m.noticiasdegipuzkoa.com/2014/10/15/ocio-y-cultura/benigno-oreja-pionero-de-la-urologia-en-euskadi here]</ref> His paternal grandfather was a physician.<ref>Urkia Etxabe 2014</ref> His father, [[Basilio Oreja Echaniz]], settled in the [[Biscay (province)|Biscay]] Ibarrangelu and since the late 1870s also practiced as a doctor,<ref>he is first time mentioned in ''Anuario-almanaque del comercio, de la industria, de la magistratura y de la administración'' of 1879, p. 1215, see [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0005044917&page=1215 here]</ref> in the early 20th century briefly serving also as a mayor.<ref>listed as alcalde in 1900 and 1902, compare ''Annual del comercio, de la industria, de la magistratura y de la administraction'', 2 (1900), p. 545, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0005257317&page=545& here]; in 1899 and 1904 he is listed as "medico", compare [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0005238401&page=483& here]</ref> Marcelino's mother, Cecilia Elósegui Ayala, came from a distinguished and much branched Gipuzkoan family.<ref>Urkia Etxabe 2014</ref> His older brothers were active in the [[Names of the Basque Country (in Spanish)|Vascongadas]] branch of Carlism during the late [[Restoration (Spain)|Restoration]] period already. Basilio died early.<ref>''La Lectura Dominical'' 20.06.14 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001674925&page=12 here]</ref> [[:es:Benigno Oreja Elosegui|Benigno]] made his name as a physician and one of [[urology]] pioneers in Gipuzkoa.<ref>see ''Benigno Oreja'' entry at ''Colegio Oficial de Médicos de Gipuzkoa'' website, available [http://www.gisep.org/es_benigno_oreja.aspx here]; he was also active in the Carlist medical service during the Civil War, see Manuel Solórzano Sánchez, ''Las Margaritas. Enfermeras del Partido Carlista'', [in:] ''Enfermeria avanza'' service available [http://enfeps.blogspot.com/2010/01/las-margaritas-enfermeras-del-partido.html here]</ref> [[Ricardo Oreja Elósegui|Ricardo]] became one of the Gipuzkoan party leaders; he was elected to the [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]] in 1920 and 1923,<ref>see ''Indice Historico de los Diputados'' at the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%2882390%29.NDIP. here]</ref> during the [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primo de Rivera]] dictatorship serving as gobernador civil of the [[Santander province]].<ref>''La Vanguardia'' 03.03.25, compare also [http://www.fundaciontelefonica.com/arte_cultura/patrimonio/archivo_fotografico/?detalle=6169 here], some internet sources wrongly claim it was Marcelino performing the governor role, see e.g. [http://www.muchocastro.com/phpbb/viewtopic.php?f=18&t=4955 here]</ref> Both were members of the [[Francoist]] [[Cortes Españolas|Cortes]] in the 1950s and 1960s.<ref>see ''Indice Historico de los Diputados'' available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/indiceHistorico&letra=o here]</ref>
Marcelino Oreja was born to his parents rather late,<ref>the exact birth year remains somewhat unclear. José Luis Orella Martínez, ''El origen del primer Catolicismo social Español'', [PhD thesis, Universidad de Educación a Distancia], Madrid 2012, p. 235, claims he was born in 1896; the [http://www.myheritage.com/research?action=query&exactSearch=0&formId=master&formMode=1&qevents=List&qname=Name+fn.marcelino%2F3oreja+ln.elosegui+g.&trn=partner_Geni_lo&trp=search_bann Geni] service indicates 1894, the same year is mentioned by Roberto Villa García, ''Las elecciones de 1933 en el País Vasco y Navarra'', Madrid 2007, {{ISBN|8498491150}}, 9788498491159, p. 272; ''Marcelino Oreja Elosegui'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entzikipedia'' available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/111360 here] claims he was born in 1891</ref> much junior than his older brothers,<ref>the birth year of his brother Benigno is also unclear. Some claim it was 1878, see Santiago Casas, ''Los Cursos Internacionales Católicos de San Sebastián (1935)'', [in:] ''Sancho el Sabio'', 35 (2012), p. 152; some claim he was born in 1880, see Urkia Etxabe 2014; depending what birth of Marcelino is adopted, the difference between the two could be 11 or 18 years, see also José Antonio Martín Aguado, José R. Vilamor, ''Historia del Ya: sinfonía con final trágico'', Madrid 2012, {{ISBN|8415382502}}, 9788415382508, p. 49</ref> and was brought up in a militantly Catholic ambience.<ref>Aguado, Vilamor 2012, p. 49</ref> He studied civil engineering and graduated as ingeniero de caminos, canales y puertos,<ref>''La formación de la imagen del Colegio. La comunicación de ideas. El Think Tank. La Fundación'', [in:] ''Fundación Ingenieros de Caminos, Canales y Puertos'' website, available [http://www.fundacioncaminos.es here]/</ref> in 1925 nominated “ingeniero en practicas”.<ref>''Madrid cientifico'' 1925, p. 16, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0002259242&page=16 here] </ref> He married Purificación Aguirre Isasi, descendant to a well-to-do Gipuzkoan family. Her father, [[Toribio Aguirre Ibarzabal]], served as a [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] officer during the [[Third Carlist War]].<ref>''Marcelino Oreja habla de su padre'', [in:] ''[[Diario Vasco]]'' 01.11.09, Josemari Velez de Mendizabal, ''Unión Cerrajera S.A. Riqueza centenaria'', [in:] Josemari Velez de Mendizabal, José Ángel Barrutiabengoa, Juan Ramón Garai, ''“Ama” Cerrajera'', Donostia 2007, p. 58 (mentioned as “Second Carlist War”)</ref> He became a member of new Basque industrial elites as co-founder, one of major shareholders and directing manager of the [[metalworking]] company [[Union Cerrajera]].<ref>it specialised in supporting construction industry, manufacturing around 1,200 types of devices, Velez de Mendizabal 2007, p. 60; for shareholding structure see Velez de Mendizabal 2007, p. 55, for Aguirre’s managerial activities see p. 58 and passim</ref> The posthumous son of Marcelino and Purificación, [[Marcelino Oreja Aguirre]], was a [[Francoist]] diplomat and later Christian-Democrat politician;<ref>semi-official biography available at ''Centre Virtuel de la Connaissance sur l’Europe'' service [http://www.cvce.eu/content/publication/2010/5/6/0c68431f-c487-490c-a66b-6e422e6aad80/publishable_en.pdf here]</ref> in 2010 [[Juan Carlos de Borbon]] made him [[:es:Marquesado de Oreja|marquis of Oreja]].<ref>see the ''Official Gazette'' available [http://www.boe.es/boe/dias/2010/04/09/pdfs/BOE-A-2010-5683.pdf here]</ref>
==Catholic activist== [[File:Iglesia de Santa Lucía (Estatua).JPG|thumbnail|160px|left|[[Angel Herrera Oria]]]] Profoundly religious though falling short of exalted religiosity,<ref>e.g. he rejected approaches by a visionary, Francisco Patxi Goicoechea, see William A. Christian, ''Visionaries: The Spanish Republic and the Reign of Christ'', Berkeley 1996, {{ISBN|0520200403}}, 9780520200401, pp. 60, 453</ref> Oreja commenced his public activity during the academic period in the very last years of the Restoration era. In early 1920 he entered [[:es:Asociación Católica de Propagandistas|Asociación Católica Nacional de Propagandistas]],<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 289, Pedro Fernández Barbadillo, ''El día en que los socialistas asesinaron a Marcelino Oreja'', [in:] ''Libertad Digital Historia'', 01.06.11, available [http://www.libertaddigital.com/opinion/historia/el-dia-en-que-los-socialistas-asesinaron-a-marcelino-oreja-1276239062.html here]</ref> the lay Catholics organization founded back in 1909.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 289, Fernández Barbadillo 2011</ref> Seconded by ACNdP, later that year he commenced work on launching a conservative academic union, [[Asociación Nacional de Estudiantes Católicos Españoles]], set up and confederated with [[Confederación Internacional de Estudiantes Católicos]].<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, pp. 231-233</ref> Based in [[Madrid]], Oreja emerged as number two in the organization, becoming its secretary general;<ref>''Marcelino Oreja Elosegui'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'', also Fernández Barbadillo 2011. The president was Fernando Martín Sánchez-Julia, Orella Martínez 2012, p. 235</ref> he is credited for “inflammatory<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 446</ref> harangues, opposing [[secularism]] in education and advocating Catholic integrity as an academic foundation.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 232</ref> Some time afterwards, still acting on ACNdP initiative, he went on to build another Christian youth organization, [[Juventud Católica Española]], somewhat broader in scope than CEC and more tied up with the parochial network. In 1924 Oreja entered its first Comisión Ejecutiva and became member of the propaganda section,<ref>Chiaki Watanabe, ''La Juventud Católica Española.Orígenes y primer desarrollo'', [in:] ''Espacio, Tiempo y Forma'', 8 (1995), pp. 133-134</ref> travelling extensively across Spain, organizing JCE structures and taking part in various congresses,<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, pp. 316-317</ref> described as “vibrant and effusive” speaker.<ref>Francisco Cervera, ''Ángel Ayala, S.I.'', Madrid 2009, {{ISBN|978-84-96860-51-3}}, p. 286</ref> [[File:News room new york times 02106u.tif|thumbnail|220px|[[New York Times|NYT]] newsroom]] In 1925 Oreja joined the ACNdP executive, nominated consejero nacional of the organization<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 235</ref> and rising to one of its key figures, on friendly terms with [[Angel Herrera Oria]]. In the mid-1920s<ref>Aguado, Vilamor 2012, p. 49 claims it was in 1920</ref> Herrera dispatched him to the [[United States]],<ref>Alicia Tapia López, ''La enseñanza de la documentación en la escuela de periodismo de «El Debate». Antecedentes y evolución posterior (1989 [sic!]-1971)'', [in:] ''Documentación de las Ciencias de la Información'' 24 (2001), p. 222, wrongly claims it was Ricardo not Marcelino</ref> the key purpose having been management training. Oreja enrolled at [[Columbia University]], studying administration and journalism;<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 436, Aguado, Vilamor 2012, p. 49</ref> he was also gaining hands-on familiarity with top American newspapers, collaborating with ''[[Boston Globe]]'' and ''[[New York Times]]''.<ref>Oreja Aguirre, ''Antecedentes…''</ref> He remained in the US for two years.<ref>Aguado, Vilamor 2012, p. 49</ref> Upon his return, Oreja praised efficiency of modern American Catholic organizations like [[:es:Caballeros de Colón|Caballeros de Colón]] and warned against the Jewish influence in the US.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 246</ref> Back in Spain, ACNdP seconded him to ''[[El Debate]]'', a dynamic daily owned by a controlled publishing house, [[Editorial Católica]];<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, pp. 66-68</ref> Oreja entered the executive board and became its manager.<ref>''Marcelino Oreja Elosegui'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia''</ref> He is credited for setting up an affiliated journalism school, renovating [[Linotype machine|linotype]] infrastructure, introducing new techniques of editing and innovative advertising strategies.<ref>Aguado, Vilamor 2012, p. 49-50</ref>
==Manager== [[File:Obrascon bond.JPG|thumbnail|240px|left|[[Obrascón]] bond]] In the late 1920s Oreja had to leave Madrid due to family reasons and returned to the Vascongadas;<ref>Aguado, Vilamor 2012, p. 49. No information on exact nature of these “family duties” is provided, though this could simply refer to his marriage</ref> instead of his home Biscay he settled in Gipuzkoa, moving into the family estate of his wife in Mondragón. In 1927 he commenced business activity related to his vocation as an engineer, becoming a manager of [[Vidrieras Españolas]],<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 235</ref> a [[Bilbao]]-based glass and mirror company.<ref>see fundacionvicrile service [http://www.fundacionvicrila.com/archivos/201303/1945-6-29-madrid-abc.pdf?1 here], later Vicasa S.A; in the 1990s the company merged with the French giant Saint Gobain</ref> In 1928 he set up his own enterprise, [[Agromán]],<ref>Fernández Barbadillo 2011, also Juan Ramón Garai Bengoa, ''Celestino Uriarte: Clandestinidad y Resistencia Comunista'', Tafalla 2008, {{ISBN|8481365246}}, 9788481365245, p. 32. The company was favored during the Francoist times, see Juan Miguel Baquero, ''Qué empresas usaron a esclavos del franquismo?'', [in:] ''El Diario'' 26.04.14, available [http://www.eldiario.es/andalucia/empresas-usaron-esclavos-franquismo_0_251975222.html here]; in 1995 it was absorbed by Ferrovial, see [http://www.ferrovial.com/es/Nuestra-compania/Historia?_afrLoop=1650039679376853&_afrWindowMode=0&_afrWindowId=null#%40%3F_afrWindowId%3Dnull%26_afrLoop%3D1340784450904483%26wcnav.model%3D%25252Foracle%25252Fwebcenter%25252Fportalapp%25252Fnavigations%25252Fnavegacion_es%26_afrWindowMode%3D0%26_adf.ctrl-state%3Dgo0b0m33k_4 here]</ref> specializing in construction work and gaining governmental contracts.<ref>E.g. at the Universidad Central refurbishment works, see ''ABC'' 24.07.1930 available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1930/07/24/018.html here]</ref> In 1929 he became secretary of Consejo Administracion of [[Obrascón]],<ref>Jaime de la Fuente (ed.), De Obrascón a OHL. Crónica de un centenario, 1911-2011, Bilbao 2011, p. 70</ref> a Bilbao construction agglomerate managed by a Carlist politician [[José Joaquín de Ampuero y del Río]], also favored during the Primo de Rivera dictatorship.<ref>Fuente 2011, p. 44</ref> In early 1930s Marcelino Oreja succeeded his father-in-law as managing director of Unión Cerrajera,<ref>Fernández Barbadillo 2011, Sharryn Kasmir, ''The Myth of Mondragon: Cooperatives, Politics, and Working Class Life in a Basque Town'', New York 1996, {{ISBN|0791430030}}, 9780791430033 p. 59 says it was in 1933, the same date is given by Barrutiabengoa 2007, p. 122</ref> at that time somewhat of a hybrid between a typical [[joint-stock company]] and a [[cooperative]].<ref>it became a mythical model of a Basque cooperative, allegedly defying the social class conflict within a framework of an integrated Basque industrial community, see Kasmir 1996, esp. the chapter ''Making the Myth of Mondragon'', pp. 15-40</ref> Some authors claim that during his term Oreja transformed Union into one of the greatest Biscay businesses,<ref>Jose Maria Codon, ''La tradicion en Jose Antonio y el sindicalismo en Mella'', Madrid 1962, chapter 6: ''Marcelino Oreja Elosegui o la accion social'', pp. 24. The company is referred to as “todopoderosa”, see ''Marcelino Oreja habla…''</ref> the others acknowledge its dynamics with some 1,500 employees, but do not credit Oreja for its growth.<ref>Velez de Mendizabal, Barrutiabengoa, Garai 2007; the authors at one point straightforwardly dub him “Marcelino the swine”, see p. 122</ref> [[File:Union Cerrajera sarrera Arrasate.jpg|thumbnail|220px|Union Cerrajera main building]] Oreja represented a new breed of managers, attempting to defuse social conflict with a social-Catholic mixture of papal teachings of [[Pope Leo XIII|Leo XIII]] and traditionalist [[corporativism]] of [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]]. To promote this vision he co-founded [[Agrupación Vasca de Acción Social Cristiana]] in 1931,<ref>and became member of its first Junta Directiva, presided by Jose Antonio Aguirre, see Iñaki Mirena Anasagasti Olabeaga, ''Acción social Cristiana para salvar la sociedad'', [in:] ''ianasgasti.blogs'' available [http://ianasagasti.blogs.com/mi_blog/2013/02/acci%C3%B3n-social-cristiana-para-salvar-la-sociedad.html here]</ref> though he was able to test its feasibility at Union Cerrajera. As a manager he remained attentive to questions of workplace safety, social insurance and education;<ref>e.g. attempting to open a vocational school in Mondragon, see ''La Escuela de Aprendices'', [in:] Josemari Velez de Mendizabal Azkarraga, ''Unión Cerrajera S.A, un patrimonio de cien años'', available [http://www.euskonews.com/0356zbk/gaia35601es.html here]. Entirely different opinion is expressed by the very same author at Velez de Mendizabal 2007, p. 77, where he claims that Oreja opposed vocational schools</ref> in 1933 he drafted the statute of [[Hermandad de Trabajadores de Unión Cerrajera]], a Catholic [[trade union]] eventually set up after his death.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 235; Velez de Mendizabal 2007, p. 64 when discussing the emergence of HETRUC mentions neither Oreja nor the Catholic character of the union</ref> However, he was vehemently hostile to competitive visions of labor relations, denouncing both [[Fascism]]<ref>Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 1975, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, p. 167 claims Oreja opposed Fascism due to its exaltation of an omnipotent state. Some highly partisan authors claim exactly the opposite and link Oreja with fascism, see Erlantz Cantabrana Berrio, ''Breve memoria - historia (subjectiva) del siglo XX y XXI'', s.l. 2010, entry ''1934. Fascismo. Marcelino Oreja Elosegui''</ref> and [[Marxism]].<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 167. The issue is not entirely clear. Marcelina Oreja is also alleged to have launched a co-operative project in Ermue, which demonstrated conciliatory approach towards the socialists and the communists, see Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''Carlos Hugo frente a Juan Carlos. La solución federal para España que Franco rechazó'', Pamplona 2014, {{ISBN|8477682658}}, 9788477682653, p. 79</ref> Having developed a reputation for being authoritarian,<ref>Kasmir 1996, p. 59</ref> he was considered prime enemy by the local [[Unión General de Trabajadores|UGT]] branch,<ref>and dubbed him “swine”, see Josemari Velez de Mendizabal Azkarraga, ''75 años de la revolución de octubre'' [in:] ''Euskonews'' service, available [http://www.euskonews.com/0502zbk/gaia50202es.html here], also ''El último revolucionario'', [in:] ''[[Diario Vasco]]'' 30.04.06, available [http://www.diariovasco.com/pg060430/prensa/noticias/AltoDeba/200604/30/DVA-ALD-000.html here]</ref> especially that Oreja pledged never to employ a [[PSOE|socialist]] or an [[Anarchism in Spain|anarchist]],<ref>“antes de que cualquier republicano pise el suelo de mi fábrica tendrá que comer hierba”, quoted after Garai Bengoa 2008, p. 17; in other references “republicano” is substituted with “socialista”, “sindicalista” etc., see e.g. ''[[Diario Vasco]]'' [http://www.diariovasco.com/prensa/20061005/altodeba/exposicion-reivindica-revolucion-octubre_20061005.html here]</ref> a statement which might be indicative of both his corporativist and Basque leanings.<ref>compare Kasmir 1996, especially the chapter ''Socialism versus Basque Nationalism', pp. 56-59</ref>
==Politician== [[File:Marcelino Oreja Elosegui.png|thumbnail|180px|left|Marcelino Oreja]] Following in footsteps of his older brothers, as a teenager Oreja was active in local Carlist structures; together with Ricardo and Benigno he defected to the secessionist [[Mellismo|Mellist]] branch of Traditionalism in 1919.<ref>it is not clear what political party he joined. The original mellist party was [[:es:Partido Católico Tradicionalista|Partido Católico Tradicionalista]], and Oreja is reported as representing it as late as 1931, see [http://www.cozar.info/cozpol1931.htm here] and [http://www.historiaelectoral.com/e1931.html here]. According to other sources it was [[:es:Partido Social Popular|Partido Social Popular]], see Orella Martínez 2012, pp. 235</ref> After the Primo de Rivera coup he engaged in collaboration with the regime, though its nature remains unspecified.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 235. His brother Ricardo was civil governor of Santander province</ref> During the [[dictablanda]] period he came out with his first major proposal, presented to the orphaned primoderiveristas: instead of building a successor to [[Spanish Patriotic Union|Union Patriotica]], named [[:es:Unión Monárquica Nacional|Union Monarquica Nacional]],<ref>some sources claim the opposite, namely that he co-founded UMN, see Javier Real Cuesta, ''Los partidos monárquicos en Vizcaya durante la Segunda República'', [in:] ''Estudios de Deusto: revista de la Universidad de Deusto'', 57 (2009), p. 216</ref> he suggested to build a social-Catholic confederation of regionalist movements across Spain.<ref>the confederation was supposed to be headed by Rafael Benjumea y Burín, conde de Guadalhorce. The organization was expected to lure the primoderiveristas towards traditionalism and regionalism and to counter La Lliga , see Gonzalo Alvarez Chillida, ''José María Pemán: pensamiento y trayectoria de un monárquico (1897-1941)'', Cadiz 1996, {{ISBN|8477863059}}, 9788477863052, p. 38</ref> These plans were cancelled by fall of the monarchy and proclamation of the [[Second Spanish Republic|republic]]. In the early 1930s Oreja already emerged as one of the Basque Right leaders.<ref>Iñaki Egaña, 'Los crímenes de Franco en Euskal herria 1936-1940'', Tafalla 2009, {{ISBN|9788481365597}}, p. 23</ref>
During the first republican [[Spanish general election, 1931|electoral campaign of 1931]] Oreja, still representing the mellistas,<ref>see [http://www.historiaelectoral.com/e1931.html here]</ref> forged an alliance with [[Partido Nacionalista Vasco|PNV]] and mainstream Carlism. It eventually materialized in Vascongadas and [[Navarre]] as [[:es:Minoría Vasco-Navarra|lista catolico-fuerista]], with Oreja [[Electoral Carlism (Second Republic)|elected as its deputy]] from the rural Biscay district.<ref>he gained 15 982 votes , see ''Indice Historico de los Diputados'' available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2882400%29.NDIP. here]. In his native Ibarranguelua he won 120 votes, only 2 more than a PNV candidate Francisco Basterrechea, see detailed results by municipality [http://www.euskadi.net/emaitzak/republica/result_1931/result_mun_prov_vizcaya_1931_c.htm here]</ref> During his first term as a deputy<ref>he did not perform any official role in the Cortes, ''ABC'' 19.03.32 available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1932/03/19/021.html here]</ref> he dedicated himself to the Basque-Navarrese<ref>though a Vizcaino living in Gipuzkoa, Oreja sympathized with the neighboring Navarre and supported the traditional Navarrese identity, see Javier Ugarte Tellería, ''Un episodio de “estilización” de la política antirrepublicana: la fiesta de San Francisco Javier de 1931 en Pamplona'', [in:]L. Castells (ed.), ''El rumor de lo cotidiano, Estudios sobre el País Vasco contemporáneo'', Bilbao 1999, p. 173</ref> autonomy, approached not as a tactical necessity, but as a matter of principle.<ref>exactly unlike most Traditionalists, see Blinkhorn 1975, p. 47. Oreja remained on friendly terms with the PNV leader, José Antonio Aguirre, and raised many eyebrows within Carlism when named Aguirre a „providencial figure”, José Antonio Vaca de Osma, ''Los vascos en la historia de España'', Madrid 1995, {{ISBN|9788432130953}}, p. 229</ref> He contributed to the so-called [[:es:Estatuto Vasco-Navarro|Estella Statute]]<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 82; detailed though highly partisan account in José María Jimeno Jurío, ''Navarra jamás dijo no al Estatuto Vasco'', Tafalla 1997, {{ISBN|848136021X}}, 9788481360219</ref> and kept supporting autonomous regulations even when the government-imposed draft moved religious issues from regional to central portfolio.<ref>''Marcelino Oreja Elosegui'' entry at ''Auñamendi'', also Manuel Ferrer Muñoz, ''La Cuestión estatutaria en Navarra durante la Segunda República', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 52 (1991), p. 206</ref> Another thread of his parliamentary activity – often merged with the Basque cause - was opposing secularization motions of the Left and backing the Church,<ref>compare his speech as follows: "si expulsáis a la Compañía de Jesús de España porque no la consideráis española, nosotros podremos decir que siempre la consideramos vasca, porque vasco es su fundador, y su organización está ínfimamente unida con el alma vasca. Os hablo con el corazón lacerado… Os aseguro que cuando aprobéis este artículo habréis declarado la lucha civil espiritual en aquellas provincias", quoted after [http://eduguridi.webcindario.com/Los%20arrecifes%20baskos5.htm this site]</ref> especially trying to preserve its education infrastructure.<ref>Oreja Aguirre, ''Antecedentes…''</ref> [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|Carlist standard]] Supporting reunification of Carlism<ref>he was active in reunification meetings as early as January 1932, taking part in huge Carlist meetings in Biscay, see Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''María Rosa Urraca Pastor: de la militancia en Acción Católica a la palestra política carlista (1900-1936)'', [in:] ''Historia y politica'' 26 (2011), p. 210</ref> in 1932 Oreja joined its united organization, [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]], though he remained relatively lukewarm to dynastical issues and supported broad monarchical alliances on national<ref>see Real Cuesta, p. 222</ref> or regional basis.<ref>like Centro Electoral Autonomo in Bilbao in local elections, see ''ABC'' 07.02.33, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1933/02/07/032.html here]; Real Cuesta p. 225</ref> He was heading the Biscay section of [[Requetés|Requeté]], a rapidly growing Carlist paramilitary militia.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 17.11.34</ref> He successfully represented the party during the [[Spanish general election, 1933|1933 electoral campaign]] to the Cortes,<ref>detailed electoral analysis, including Oreja’s performance, in Villa García 2007. He lost in Ibarranguelua to both PNV candidates. See also [http://www.euskadi.net/emaitzak/republica/result_1933_elecciones/result_mun_prov_vizcaya_1933_c.htm here] and ''Indice Historico'' available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=1-1&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2882400%29.NDIP. here]</ref> again standing in the Biscay province and again in alliance with PNV.<ref>unlike in 1931, the alliance with PNV was strictly provincial, Villa García 2007, pp. 50-51</ref> As late as November 1933 he still advocated the apparently doomed autonomy “contra viento y marea”,<ref>“against all odds”, ''ABC'' 11.11.33, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1933/11/11/032.html here]</ref> which, however, did not amount to endorsing Basque nationalism or Basque separatism.<ref>growing in the Basque milieu, Oreja was an ethnic Basque, though his father Basilio – a Basque himself - allegedly banned his sons to speak Basque at home, see [http://gananzia.com/jaime-mayor-oreja-mondragon here]. Marcelino Oreja considered himself Basque in a traditionalist sense, e.g. member of the Spanish political nation</ref> Some scholars oppose him to “integristas” in the autonomy discourse.<ref>Real Cuesta, p. 226</ref>
During the [[:es:Revolución de Asturias de 1934|revolution of 1934]], the tension in Mondragon was running high.<ref>a popular and dramatized account [http://ccaa.elpais.com/ccaa/2014/10/04/paisvasco/1412445405_795176.html here]; the most controversial account in Garai Bengoa 2008</ref> Oreja was arrested in his home by socialist militiamen, reportedly employees of the company he managed. Following a brief detention, he was shot dead.<ref>''Marcelino Oreja habla…''; details in Garai Bengoa 2008, pp. 42-50</ref>
==Legacy== Oreja was the best known single victim of the 1934 revolution in Spain, as no other parliamentary deputy was killed during the turmoil.<ref>Stanley G. Payne, ''Spain's First Democracy: The Second Republic, 1931-1936'', Madison 1993, {{ISBN|0299136744}}, 9780299136741, p. 220</ref> His death has long reverberated in the national public debate. The Right presented it as a proof of barbarian and Bolshevik nature of the Left, a prefiguration of the future bloody terror, to be imposed by the mass workers’ movements.<ref>see e.g. ''El Siglo Futuro'' 06.10.1934 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000531079&page=6 here]</ref> For the Carlists, Oreja became another of their martyrs; the following year he was already honored during Fiesta de los Mártires de la Tradición, the feast dedicated to the fallen Carlists and observed every March from 1895.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 218</ref> In the Francoist Spain many streets have been named after him. Today “calle Marcelino Oreja” exists, among other places, in Bilbao and [[Mislata]]. [[File:Esq vte blasco ib con marce oreja.jpg|thumbnail|''calle Marcelino Oreja'', Mislata]] The public memory of Marcelino Oreja Elósegui has been kept alive mostly thanks to his son, Marcelino Oreja Aguirre, who remained a well-known figure in Spain until the late 20th century. Today the Basques usually appreciate Oreja's work on the Basque autonomy, though they tend to ignore his Carlist political identity;<ref>''Marcelino Oreja Elosegui'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entzikipedia''</ref> the Leftist-minded Basques view the Basque and the socialist cases as tantamount and consider Oreja the enemy of both.<ref>Oreja is named "personaje antivasco” by a Herri Batasuna activist, see Jon Idigoras, ''El hijo de Juanita Gerrikabeitia'', Tafalla 2000, {{ISBN|8481361496}}, 9788481361490, p. 77</ref> In the Carlist historical discourse he does not figure prominently.<ref>compare a sixtinos fraction of Carlism service [http://www.carlismo.es/?s=oreja here]</ref> In the partisan debates of current-day Spanish politics he is sometimes acknowledged in relation to [[Jaime Mayor Oreja]], depending on political preferences mentioned either with hostility.<ref>see ''press.o.s.'' site [http://amnistiapresos.blogspot.com/2011/10/pablo-hasel-el-compromiso-de-la.html here]</ref>
==See also== * [[Carlism]] * [[Basque nationalism|Basque Nationalism]] * [[Corporatism]] * [[Second Spanish Republic]]
==Footnotes== {{Reflist|3}}
==Further reading== * Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 1975, {{ISBN|9780521207294}} * Sharryn Kasmir, ''The Myth of Mondragon. Cooperatives, Politics and Working-Class Life in a Basque Town'', New York 1996, {{ISBN|0791430030}} * José Luis Orella Martínez, ''El origen del primer Catolicismo social Español'', [PhD thesis at Universidad de Educación a Distancia], Madrid 2012 * Josemari Velez de Mendizabal, José Ángel Barrutiabengoa, Juan Ramón Garai, ''“Ama” Cerrajera'', Donostia 2007
==External links== * [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/111360 Marcelino Oreja Elósegui in the Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia] * [http://www.diariovasco.com/20091101/alto-deba/marcelino-oreja-habla-padre-20091101.html Marcelino Oreja about his father] * [http://www.diariovasco.com/pg060430/prensa/noticias/AltoDeba/200604/30/DVA-ALD-000.html 1934 Revolutionaries] * [http://www.libertaddigital.com/opinion/historia/el-dia-en-que-los-socialistas-asesinaron-a-marcelino-oreja-1276239062.html The death of Marcelino Oreja] * [http://www.euskonews.com/0600zbk/gaia60001es.html Revolution of 1934 in the Basque Country] * [http://www.rumbos.net/ocja/jaoc0074.html Parliamentary homage to Marcelino Oreja by Jóse Antonio] * [https://es.wikisource.org/wiki/Estatuto_de_Estella Estella Statute text] * [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%2882400%29.NDIP. Historical Index of Deputies] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vq3vWInEhcE Errekete (Euskara)] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uhK1ER3B4Hg ''Vizcainos! Por Dios y por España''; contemporary Carlist propaganda]

{{update|date=May 2017}} <!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> [[Image:LocationNepal.svg|thumb|The location of Nepal]] [[Image:Modern Nepal Map.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal]]]] {{double image|right|Flag of Nepal.svg|110|Emblem of Nepal.svg|160|The [[Flag of Nepal]]|The [[Coat of arms of Nepal]]}}
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Nepal:
'''[[Nepal]]''' is a landlocked sovereign state in [[South Asia]]. The country is bordered to the north by [[China]], and to the south, east, and west by [[India]]. The [[Himalayas]] in the country's northern region has eight of the world's ten highest mountains, including [[Mount Everest]], called Sagarmatha in Nepali.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== General reference == [[Image:Nepal-CIA WFB Map.png|thumb|An enlargeable basic map of [[Nepal]]]] * [[International Phonetic Alphabet|Pronunciation]]:nɛpɑːl * Common English country name: Nepal * Official English country name: The [[Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): Nepali * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): Nepalese (also 'Nepali') * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of Nepal]] * [[International rankings of Nepal]] * [[ISO country codes]]: NP, NPL, 524 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:NP]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.np]]
== Geography of Nepal == [[Image:Nepal topo en.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Nepal]]]]
[[Geography of Nepal]] * Nepal is: a [[landlocked country]] * Location: ** [[Northern Hemisphere]] and [[Eastern Hemisphere]] ** [[Eurasia]] *** [[Asia]] **** [[South Asia]] ***** [[Indian subcontinent]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[Nepal Time]] ([[UTC+05:45]]) ** Extreme points of Nepal *** High: [[Mount Everest]] {{convert|8848|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} – highest point on [[Earth]] ** Land boundaries: 2,926 km ::{{Flag|India}} 1,690 km ::{{Flag|China}} 1,236 km :* Coastline: ''none'' * [[Nepal Geological Society]] * [[Population of Nepal]]: 26,494,504(2011) - [[List of countries by population|41st most populous country]] * * [[Area of Nepal]]: 147,181 km<sup>2</sup> * [[:commons:Atlas of Nepal|Atlas of Nepal]]
=== Environment of Nepal === [[Image:Satellite image of Nepal in October 2002.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable satellite image of [[Nepal]]]]

=== Religion in Nepal === [[Religion in Nepal]] – over 30% of the population follow Hinduism (see [[#Hinduism in Nepal|Hinduism in Nepal]] below). * [[Kopan Monastery]] * [[Lumbini]]
==== Buddhism in Nepal ==== [[Buddhism in Nepal]] – though a minority faith in the country, Buddhism is linked historically with Nepal.
=====Buddhist temples in Nepal===== * [[Boudhanath]] * [[Swayambhunath]] * [[Lumbini|Mayadevi Temple]] * [http://kirtipur.org/ Kagyu Institute of Buddhist Studies - KIBS]
==== Hinduism in Nepal ==== [[Hinduism in Nepal]] – practised by about 80% of Nepalese. revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2011}} This is a list of '''public holidays (national or otherwise) in Chile'''; about half of them are Christian holidays.
== Dates for the year 2018 == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Month !! style="width:90px;"| Day !! English Name !! Local Name !! Remarks |- | rowspan=4 | January || 1 <small>(Monday)</small> || [[New Year's Day]] || ''Año Nuevo'' || [[Blue law]]s forbid opening of most services. |- | 16 <small>(Tuesday)</small> || [[Pope Francis]]' visit || ''visita del Papa Francisco'' || This is a regional holiday, '''valid only in the [[Santiago Metropolitan Region]]'''.<ref name="law_21065">{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=1113434&idParte=&idVersion=2018-01-10 |title=law 21,065 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=January 11, 2018}}</ref> |- | 17 <small>(Wednesday)</small> || [[Pope Francis]]' visit || ''visita del Papa Francisco'' || This is a regional holiday, '''valid only in the [[Araucanía Region]]'''.<ref name="law_21051">{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=1112117&idParte=&idVersion=2017-12-07 |title=law 21,051 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=January 11, 2018}}</ref> |- | 18 <small>(Thursday)</small> || [[Pope Francis]]' visit || ''visita del Papa Francisco'' || This is a regional holiday, '''valid only in the [[Tarapacá Region]]'''.<ref name="law_21051"/> |- | February || style="background:#ececec; color:gray;" colspan="4" | <small>''No holidays.''</small> |- | rowspan=2 | March || 30 <small>(Friday)</small> || [[Good Friday]] || ''Viernes Santo'' || |- | 31 <small>(Saturday)</small> || [[Holy Saturday]] || ''Sábado Santo'' || |- | April || style="background:#ececec; color:gray;" colspan="4" | <small>''No holidays.''</small> |- | rowspan=2 | May || 1 <small>(Tuesday)</small> || [[Labour Day]] || ''Día del Trabajo'' || On this day, more stores and services will close than on any other holidays, as stipulated by [[blue law]]s. |- | 21 <small>(Monday)</small> || [[Navy Day (Chile)|Navy Day]] || ''Día de las Glorias Navales'' || Commemorates the [[Battle of Iquique]]. |- | June || 7 <small>(Thursday)</small> || [[Battle of Arica]] || ''Asalto y Toma del Morro de Arica'' || This is a regional holiday, '''valid only in the [[Arica and Parinacota Region]]'''. |- | rowspan=2 | July || 2 <small>(Monday)</small> || [[Feast of Saints Peter and Paul|Saint Peter and Saint Paul]] || ''San Pedro y San Pablo'' || |- | 16 <small>(Monday)</small> || [[Our Lady of Mount Carmel]] || ''Virgen del Carmen'' || Established in 2007, it replaced [[Corpus Christi (feast)|Corpus Christi]]. The Catholic Church's official name for this day is ''Solemnidad de la Virgen del Carmen, Reina y Patrona de Chile'', but the law that created this holiday (20,148) does not use it.<ref name="law_20148">{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=257080&idParte=&idVersion=2007-01-06 |title=law 20,148 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> |- | rowspan=2 | August || 15 <small>(Wednesday)</small> || [[Assumption of Mary]] || ''Asunción de la Virgen'' || |- | 20 <small>(Monday)</small> || Nativity of Liberator [[Bernardo O'Higgins]] || ''Nacimiento del Prócer de la Independencia'' || This is a local holiday, '''valid only in the communes of [[Chillán]] and [[Chillán Viejo]]'''. |- | rowspan=3 | September || 17 <small>(Monday)</small> || [[National Day|National holiday]] || ''[[Fiestas Patrias (Chile)|Fiestas Patrias]]'' || |- | 18 <small>(Tuesday)</small> || [[National Day|National holiday]] || ''[[Fiestas Patrias (Chile)|Fiestas Patrias]]'' || Celebrates the establishment of the [[Government Junta of Chile (1810)|First Government Council]] in 1810. |- | 19 <small>(Wednesday)</small> || [[Army Day]] || ''Día de las Glorias del Ejército'' || |- | October || 15 <small>(Monday)</small> || [[Columbus Day]] || ''Día del Descubrimiento de Dos Mundos'' || Colloquially known as ''Día de la Raza'' ("Race Day") or formally by its older name (''Aniversario del Descubrimiento de América''). |- | rowspan=2 | November || 1 <small>(Thursday)</small> || [[All Saints' Day|All Saints]] || ''Día de Todos los Santos'' || |- | 2 <small>(Friday)</small> || [[Reformation Day]] || ''Día Nacional de las Iglesias Evangélicas y Protestantes'' || Established in 2008. This holiday moves in relation to the day of week.<ref name="law_20299"/> |- | rowspan=2 | December || 8 <small>(Saturday)</small> || [[Feast of the Immaculate Conception|Immaculate Conception]] || ''Inmaculada Concepción'' || |- | 25 <small>(Tuesday)</small> || [[Christmas Day]] || ''Navidad'' / ''Natividad del Señor'' || |}
==History== On January 28, 1915, [[President of Chile]] [[Ramón Barros Luco]] promulgated law 2,977,<ref name="law_2977">{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=23639&idParte=&idVersion=1915-02-01 |title=law 2,977 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> which arranged all the information insofar about holidays celebrated in Chile. It established or kept the following holidays:
#Sundays year-round. #January 1 ([[Feast of the Circumcision of Christ]] at the time; [[New Year]] in the late 20th and 21st centuries), June 29 ([[Feast of Saints Peter and Paul|Saint Peter and Saint Paul]]), August 15 ([[Assumption of Mary]]), December 8 ([[Immaculate Conception]]), December 25 ([[Christmas Day]]), and the floating holidays of the [[Ascension of Jesus Christ]] and [[Corpus Christi (feast)|Corpus Christi]]. #Fridays and Saturdays during [[Holy Week]]. #September 18, Establishment of the [[Government Junta of Chile (1810)|First Government Junta]] in 1810. #September 19 and May 21, in celebration of the glories of the Army and the Navy. #The day of election of electors of the President of the Republic.
The same law abolished, by omission, four religious holidays: [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]] ("Adoración de los Santos Reyes", January 6), [[Carnival]] ("Carnaval", mobile), [[Annunciation]] ("Anunciación del Señor", march 25) and [[Nativity of the Theotokos|Nativity of the Virgin Mary]] ("Natividad de la Virgen", September 8). It also shortened the [[Fiestas Patrias (Chile)|national independence holiday]] to two days (until 1914, they occupied September 18, 19 and 20).
On November 14, 1921, President [[Arturo Alessandri Palma]] promulgated Law 3,810,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=24262&idParte=&idVersion=1921-11-24 |title=law 3,810 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> marking October 12 ([[Columbus Day]]) as holiday.
On April 30, 1931, President [[Carlos Ibáñez del Campo]] promulgated the "Decree Enforceable as Law" ("Decreto con Fuerza de Ley") 130, marking May 1 ([[May Day]]) as holiday.
In 1932, Provisional President [[Bartolomé Blanche]] reinstated the September 20 holiday,<ref>Decree-law 636, published in the 17/09/1932 edition of the Diario Oficial.</ref> which existed until 1944.<ref>Law 8,223, published in the 13 September 1945 edition of the Diario Oficial.</ref>
In 1968, the holidays of [[Feast of Saints Peter and Paul|Saint Peter and Saint Paul]], [[Ascension of Jesus Christ]] and [[Corpus Christi (feast)|Corpus Christi]] were eliminated by Article 144 of Law 16,840.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=28681&idParte=&idVersion=1979-12-29 |title=Law 16,840 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> The Catholic Church agreed to celebrate them on the nearest Sunday.
September 11 (the day of the [[Chilean coup of 1973|military coup in 1973]]) was established as a holiday (''Día de la Liberación Nacional'', "Day of National Liberation") by the military regime in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=29453&idParte=&idVersion=2002-03-06 |title=Law 18,026 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> In 1998 it was replaced by the ''Día de la Unidad Nacional'' ("Day of National Unity"),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=127036&idParte=&idVersion=2002-03-06 |title=Law 19,588 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> to be observed the first Monday in September. In March 2002 the latter was abolished.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=195243&idParte=&idVersion=2002-03-06 |title=Law 19,793 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>
The holiday on June 29 ([[Feast of Saints Peter and Paul|Saint Peter and Saint Paul]]) was reestablished in September 1985.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=29840&idParte=&idVersion=1985-09-17 |title=Law 18,432 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>
In 1987, during a visit by [[Pope John Paul II]], [[Corpus Christi (feast)|Corpus Christi]] was reestablished<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=29998&idParte=&idVersion=1987-04-14 |title=Law 18,607 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> (although the Church continued to observe the holiday on the nearest Sunday<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jesus.cl/iglesia/paso_iglesia/documentos/conf/documentos_sini.ficha.php?mod=documentos_sini&id=370&sw_volver=yes&descripcion= |title=Declaración sobre feriado de Corpus Christi (01/06/1987) |publisher=Jesus.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>).
On March 10, 2000, Law 19,668<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=160270&idParte=&idVersion=2007-01-06 |title=Law 19,668 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> moved the [[Feast of Saints Peter and Paul|Saint Peter and Saint Paul]], [[Columbus Day]] and [[Corpus Christi (feast)|Corpus Christi]] holidays to the preceding Monday, if they were to fall on a Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, or to the following Monday, if they were to fall on a Friday. Additionally, the designation of [[Columbus Day]] was changed from ''Aniversario del Descubrimiento de América'' to ''Día del Descubrimiento de Dos Mundos'' ("Discovery of Two Worlds' Day"), an obvious corruption from the then-recent ubiquitous "Encuentro de dos mundos" ("The Meeting of Two Worlds") slogan. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.educarchile.cl/Portal.Base/Web/VerContenido.aspx?ID=76773 |title=Encuentro de dos mundos |publisher=Educarchile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0008/000875/087520SB.pdf |title=CONMEMORACIÓN DEL QUINTO CENTENARIO DEL ENCUENTRO DE DOS MUNDOS (1492–1992) |format=PDF |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buquedepapel.com/editoriales/141-1992-el-ano-del-encuentro-de-dos-mundos |title=1992: el año del encuentro de dos mundos |publisher=Buquedepapel.com |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> <ref>[http://www.schoolholidaysguide.com/articles/celebran-el-encuentro-de-dos-mundos/ Celebran el encuentro de dos mundos]</ref> <ref>[http://www2.cesla.uw.edu.pl/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=94&Itemid=77 500 ańos del encuentro de dos mundos. Una perspectiva polaca.]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
On January 6, 2007, Law 20,148<ref name="law_20148"/> replaced [[Corpus Christi (feast)|Corpus Christi]] with [[Our Lady of Mount Carmel]], to be observed July 16, starting that year.
On September 14, 2007, Law 20,215.<ref name="law_20215">{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=264651&idParte=&idVersion=2007-09-14 |title=Law 20,215 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref> declared holidays all September 17s falling on a Monday and all September 20s falling on a Friday.
On October 11, 2008, Law 20,299<ref name="law_20299">{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=279294&idParte=&idVersion=2008-10-11 |title=Law 20,299 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> established [[Reformation Day]] on October 31 as a national holiday, starting that year. This holiday is moved to the preceding Friday if it falls on a Tuesday, or to the following Friday if it falls on a Wednesday.
On April 30, 2013, Law 20,663 established the regional [[Battle of Arica]] holiday, to be observed only in the [[Arica and Parinacota]] region.<ref name="law_20663">{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=1050508&idVersion=2013-04-30 |title=law 20,663 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=April 30, 2013}}</ref>
On December 30, 2016, Law 20,983<ref name="law_20983">{{cite web|url=https://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=1098384&idParte=&idVersion=2016-12-30 |title=Law 20,983 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=December 31, 2016}}</ref> declared as holidays those days that are Monday January 2 or Friday September 17.
Besides yearly holidays, since 1901 presidential elections are declared holidays, as mandated by successive versions of the General Elections law (Law 18,700<ref name="law 18,700">{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=30082&idParte=&idVersion=2008-10-04 |title=Law 18,700 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> being the current one; see laws 1,464,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=22671&idParte=&idVersion=1901-06-22 |title=Law 1,464 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> 1,752,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=22892&idParte=&idVersion=1905-09-02 |title=Law 1,752 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> 2,977,<ref name="law_2977"/> decree-law 542,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=6173&idParte=&idVersion=1925-09-23 |title=decree-law 542 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> 6,250,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=25329&idParte=&idVersion=1938-09-14 |title=Law 6,250 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> 6,834, 9,334 and 12,891). Since the late 20th century, parliamentary and municipal elections are also public holidays (see Law 18,700<ref name="law 18,700"/>). Censuses, held every ten years, are also declared holidays since 1982; that year's census and 1992's were so due to ad-hoc laws;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=29540&idParte=&idVersion=1982-04-16 |title=Law 18,116 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=30483&idParte=&idVersion=1992-01-29 |title=Law 19,116 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> censuses taken from 1992 onwards are declared holidays due to a reform in the Census law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=194251&idParte=&idVersion=2002-02-01 |title=Law 19,790 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> (This did not occur in 2012, where the census was carried out in the space of two months, using a different methodology.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ilovechile.cl/2011/11/03/instituto-national-de-estadisticas-realeses-questions-censo-2012/37707 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104034445/http://ilovechile.cl/2011/11/03/instituto-national-de-estadisticas-realeses-questions-censo-2012/37707 |archivedate=November 4, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>)
===Meaning of the January 1 holiday===
Shortly after Chile's independence, an 1824 (government-approved) Church decree<ref>Boletín de Leyes y Decretos del Gobierno, 1839, tomo II, decreto de 9 de agosto de 1824, pp. 14–15</ref><ref>Peralta, Paulina (2007). ''¡Chile tiene Fiesta'', p.59. [[LOM Ediciones]], Santiago, Chile. {{ISBN|978-956-282-921-2}}.</ref> reduced the amount of religious holidays, enumerating and the surviving holidays, including the [[Feast of the Circumcision of Christ]], observed on January 1. Law 2,977 (passed in 1915, still in vigour) lists this holiday by date only, without using any name, but does treat it as religious one.<ref name="law_2977"/> However, nowadays (as of 2009) it's widely celebrated as the (civic) New Year holiday.<ref>[http://hectorvelismeza.com/libros.html El blog de Héctor Velis-Meza: Desde cuándo se celebra el año nuevo]</ref>{{Failed verification|date=February 2010}} As a matter of fact, there aren't any known regulations later than 1915 that use the "Circumcision of Christ" name, while "New Year" is used by numerous regulations of all types (laws (19.925<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=220208&idParte=&idVersion=2004-01-19 |title=Law 19,925 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>), decree-laws (''decretos ley'') (1.299,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=223598&idParte=&idVersion=1975-12-26 |title=decree-law 1,299 of 1975 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> 1.613<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=183542&idParte=&idVersion=1976-12-11 |title=decree-law 1,613 of 1976 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> and 2,408<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=177891&idParte=&idVersion=1978-12-13 |title=decree-law 2.408 of 1978 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>), decrees enforceable as law (''decretos con fuerza de ley'') (D.F.L 338 of 1960<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=5469&idParte=&idVersion=1989-09-23 |title=D.F.L. 338 of 1960 |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref>), [[ministerial decree]]s and resolutions (decree 6234 of 1929 of the Public Education Ministry<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=19451&idParte=&idVersion=2006-10-18 |title=decree 6234 of 1929 of the Public Education Ministry |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> (the oldest such regulation), decree 83 of 1985 of the Labor Ministry,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=186941&idParte=&idVersion=1985-02-19 |title=decree 83 of 1985 of the Labor Ministry |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> decree 48 of 2007 of the Labor Ministry,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=202919&idParte=&idVersion=2007-08-27 |title=decree 48 of 2007 of the Labor Ministry |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> et cetera) and municipal decrees and ordinances (decree 1316 of 2004 of the Las Condes Municipality,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=223978&idParte=&idVersion=2004-04-19 |title=decree 1316 of 2004 of the Las Condes Municipality |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> decree 23 of 2006 of the Padre Las Casas Municipality,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leychile.cl/Navegar?idNorma=256770&idParte=&idVersion=2006-12-22 |title=decree 23 of 2006 of the Padre Las Casas Municipality |publisher=Leychile.cl |accessdate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> decree 23 of 2009 of the San Carlos Municipality,<ref>{{cite {{short description|Nazi administrative subdivision}} {{refimprove|date=May 2018}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:{{lang|de|Reichsgau|nocat=y}}}} {{distinguish|text=the {{lang|de|[[Gau (German)|Gau]]}}, an administrative region of the [[NSDAP]] (Nazi Party)}} [[Image:NS_administrative_Gliederung_1944.png|thumb|300px|NSDAP administrative units, 1944.]] [[Image:Germany1941.png|thumb|300px|Map of Nazi Germany with {{lang|de|Reichsgaue}} highlighted.]] A '''{{lang|de|Reichsgau}}''' (plural {{lang|de|Reichsgaue}}) was an administrative subdivision created in a number of [[areas annexed by Nazi Germany|areas annexed]] to [[Nazi Germany]] between 1938 and 1945. ==Overview== The term was formed from the words {{lang|de|[[Reich]]}} (realm, empire) and {{lang|de|[[Gau (country subdivision)|Gau]]}}, the latter a deliberately medieval-sounding word with a meaning approximately equivalent to ''[[shire]]''. The {{lang|de|Reichsgaue}} were an attempt to resolve the administrative chaos resulting from the mutually overlapping jurisdictions and different boundaries of the [[NSDAP]] Party {{lang|de|[[Gau (country subdivision)|Gaue]]}}, placed under a Party {{lang|de|[[Gauleiter]]}}, and the [[list of historic states of Germany#States of the Weimar Republic|federal states]], under a {{lang|de|[[Reichsstatthalter]]}} responsible to the [[Ministry of the Interior (Germany)|Ministry of the Interior]] (in the [[Provinces of Prussia|Prussian provinces]], the equivalent post was that of {{lang|de|[[Oberpräsident]]}}). Interior Minister [[Wilhelm Frick]] had long desired to streamline the German administration, and the {{lang|de|Reichsgaue}} were the result: the borders of party {{lang|de|Gaue}} and those of the federal states were to be identical, and the party {{lang|de|Gauleiter}} also occupied the post of {{lang|de|Reichsstatthalter}}. Rival interests and the influence the {{lang|de|Gauleiter}} wielded with Hitler prevented any reform from being undertaken in the "[[Altreich (pre-1938 Nazi Germany)|Old Reich]]" ({{lang-de|Altreich}}) which meant Germany in its borders of 1937, before the annexation of other territories like Austria, the {{lang|de|[[Sudetenland]]|italic=no}}, and Bohemia, and the {{lang|de|Reichsgau}} scheme was therefore implemented only in newly-acquired territories. There were several {{lang|de|Reichsgaue}}: * {{lang|de|[[Ostmark (Austria)|Ostmark]]}}, formed from the formerly independent [[Federal State of Austria|Austria]] * {{lang|de|[[Sudetenland]]}}, formed from a substantial part of the German-speaking outer rim areas of the former [[Czechoslovakia]] occupied in 1938 * {{lang|de|[[Danzig-Westpreußen]]}} and {{lang|de|[[Wartheland]]}}, formed from the [[Free City of Danzig]] and areas annexed from [[Second Polish Republic|Poland]] The Ostmark was subsequently subdivided into seven smaller {{lang|de|Reichsgaue}}, generally coterminous with the former Austrian {{lang|de|Länder}} (federal provinces). ==List of {{lang|de|Reichsgaue}}== ==={{lang|de|Reichsgaue}} in Austria and in the Czech lands established in 1938=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col" | {{lang|de|Gau}} name ! scope="col" | German name ! scope="col" | Capital ! scope="col" | Established ! scope="col" | Notes |- | [[Reichsgau Kärnten|Carinthia]] | {{lang|de|Kärnten}} | {{lang|de|[[Klagenfurt]]|italic=no}} | 1938 | Formed from the former Austrian federal state of [[Carinthia (state)|Carinthia]] and [[East Tyrol|Eastern Tyrol]], included from 1941 on parts of [[Slovenia]]. |- | [[Reichsgau Niederdonau|Lower Danube]] | {{lang|de|Niederdonau}} | {{lang|de|[[Krems an der Donau|Krems]]|italic=no}} (see note) | 1938 | Formed from the former Austrian federal state of [[Lower Austria]] and northern {{lang|de|[[Burgenland]]|italic=no}}; included from 1939 on parts of southern [[Moravia]]. In 1943, Hitler toured {{lang|de|Reichsgau Niederdonau}} and assured {{lang|de|Gauleiter}} [[Hugo Jury]] that the capital would be {{lang|de|Brünn}} ({{lang|cs|[[Brno]]|italic=no}}) in the near future.Bryant, C.C. (2007).
